column2: Another April cold weather record was registered yesterday, when the temperature dropped below the previously recorded low for the second day in succession. The unusual cold extended throughout the Northeastern quarter of the country, with below freezing readings ...

PARIS, April 14--On the French front the general situation remained unchanged today, although it is still believed that the enemy may make a move, if only in the hope of delaying that "immediate and efficacious aid" that the Allies have pledged themselves to give Norway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14-- The prospect that James Stewart and Marlene Dietrich will be teamed at Warners in S.N. Behrman's "No Time for Comedy" was disclosed today. The move will necessitate negotiation by Warners of a loan-out deal with Metro for Stewart.

CHICAGO, April 14--European political developments dominated the action of the grain markets last week and, with a sudden increase in public speculative buying, wheat and corn prices advanced sharply.

Robert Ardrey, author of "Thunder Rock," which had a run of twenty-three performances following its premiere on Nov. 14, was announced yesterday as the winner of the first Sidney Howard Memorial Award, established by the Playwrights Company to foster new writing talent in the theatre.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 --An authoritative German source says the Reich contemplates requesting a change in the International Danube Commission, which includes delegates of France and Britain in addition to the riparian States but does not include a German representative.

BERLIN, April 14--Although the attention of financial circles was centered on last week's spectacular war developments, the reduction in the Reichsbank's rediscount rate from 4 to 3 per cent was considered an important milestone in the Reich's war-financing policy.

Oren Root Jr. of 455 East Fiftyseventh Street, announced yesterday that he had received a tremendous response to "declarations" he sent out last week, proposing Wendell L. Willkie for the nomination for President.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 14-- In a journey of a thousand miles completed today, from the SwedishNorwegian frontier in Lapland to Stockholm, this correspondent heard the word "German" at least a thousand times. It was on almost every tongue at every station in this white expanse of highland.

The United States now has nearly one-half of the world's total of 41,090,347 telephones and there is about one telephone for every six persons in this country, according to statistics made public yesterday by the New York Telephone Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15-- William K. Howard has been withdrawn by Warners from the direction of "The Life of Knute Rockne" and production of the film was halted today. Disagreement over the course of the story is understood to have caused the split between Howard ...

Miss Elizabeth A. Walsh, director of the Board of Education Bureau for Children With Retarded Mental Development, with headquarters at Public School 14, 224 East Twentyeighth Street, died yesterday in St.

The Norwegian-Ameirca liner Bergensfjord, which got out of Norway just in the nick of time, arrived here early yesterday with 380 passengers, 152 of whom were Norwegians and 131 United States citizens.

The first of the three American ships caught in Norway by the German invasion is free, past the danger zone and on her way home, it was learned yesterday by Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the Moore-McCormack Lines, the owners of the ship.

News from Europe became yesterday even a greater marketwise factor and the so-called "war brides," led by the aircrafts, shot into new high territory before values were pared somewhat by late profit-taking.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 15 --Great alarm was caused here by a decree issued by the Government Economic Council today forbidding the making of new contracts for exports of cereals. Contracts at present in force may be completely filled.

WASHINGTON, April 15--It was on Feb. 23, 1939, that what Wendell L. Willkie identifies as the first public attention-calling to his possibilities as a Presidential candidate appeared in this space. But in the ensuing fourteen months mention has grown into a boomlet if not a boom, and the political

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., April 15--This was certainly a great day for the trout, but it was just another opening day for the anglers of New Jersey, who turned out in thousands, and, for the most part, fished in vain.
Effective yesterday, the United Kingdom Board of Trade will require prior import licenses on a variety of non-ferrous metals and minerals and a number of certain medicinal products, according to a

WASHINGTON, April 15--President Roosevelt hopes to cast aside affairs of State tomorrow long enough to indulge himself like any average American in the national pastime. The weather permitting, he will throw out the first ball at the opening game between the Senators and the Red Sox.

Creation of a new post in the ready-to-wear division of R.H. Macy Co., Inc.., designed to put selling technique and sales personnel-customer relations in large-volume merchandising of women's outer apparel on a par with the ....

LONDON, April 15--The Admiralty and the War Office announced today that British forces had landed at several points on the Norwegian coast to meet the invading German Army. At the same time Norwegian Government officials in London announced the recapture of

WASHINGTON, April 15--The rapid expansion of the Japanese Navy, involving all categories from battleships to submarines, was discussed with frankness today before the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs by Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The Superior Oil Company will offer its $10,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1950, to the public at 100, according to an amendment filed by the company today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Tuesday, April 16 (UP)--A small chartered airliner from Boston with a pilot and three passengers aboard crashed on a farm at Higganum, ten miles southeast of here, early today and burned.
WASHINGTON, April 15--The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected the current plan for reorganization of the bankrupt Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad as not in the public interest.

The counting of New York City's millions for the sixteenth decennial census was 90 per cent complete last night, at the close of two weeks' work by 8,300 enumerators, according to Kirke D. Austin, area manager.

With a fervent prayer going up on all fronts for just a reasonable break in the weather, the major league baseball season will open today with the National League launching its sixty-fifth and the American League its fortieth championship campaign on the battlefields of eight cities.

Tonight's opening, postponed from last Thursday, is "Morning Star," the Sylvia Regan play in which Molly Picon is to make her debut in an English speaking, full-length Broadway drama. Its story is that of an immigrant family living in ....

ROME, April 15--Despite the British Admiralty statement that Allied forces had landed in several points along the Norwegian coast the Italian press today continued to feature the failure of the Allies in Scandinavia.

MONTREAL, April 15--James H. R. Cromwell delivered today at a luncheon at the Canadian Club of Montreal the second of a series of three speeches he had planned since coming to Canada as Minister of the United States. Mr. Cromwell's first speech, on "The Issues
A British official wireless broadcast recorded yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES presented an appraisal of the present condition of the German fleet.

CHICAGO, April 15--Increased tension in the political situation in Europe and a flood of unfavorable crop comments from the Southwest lifted wheat prices about 1 cent a bushel today. Commission houses were persistent buyers in small lots and more than offset the hedging

GENEVA, April 15--The story of Nazi political penetration of Danzig, which culminated in the military operations that opened the European war, was revealed today by the League of Nations with the publication of the report of Dr. Karl J. Burckhardt, who was League High Commissioner in Danzig.

Jacob Epstein's "Adam," already the subject of much discussion in England, has at length reached Fifty-seventh Street. Installed in the Academy Room of the American Fine Arts Building, our oftportrayed ancestor will remain with us until May 28.

With only three weeks and five days remaining before its opening on May 11, the World's Fair, shaking off its Winter lethargy in earnest, had its busiest day yesterday since last season as it received the vanguard of its vast army of employes ....

Hungary is preparing for any emergency, Tibor de Eckhardt, member of the Hungarian Parliament and leader of the Hungarian Farmer party, said yesterday on his arrival aboard the United States liner Manhattan.

A VERY good little boy, we were recently reminded, lived on Hollins Street in Balti more long, long ago. His name was Henry Mencken. It now develops that on Madison Street in the same city there lived, somewhat earlier, an even better little girl. Her name was Helen Thomas. The eminently Menckenian "Happy Days" told the one story.

A campaign for funds for the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees and Overseas Needs was launched by the Manhattan section of the junior division yesterday afternoon at a rally at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.

DETROIT, April 15 (AP)--George Pallage, stocky veteran from Akron, Ohio, thrilled matinee railbirds at the American Bowling Congress championships today with the seventh perfect 300 score in the forty-year history of the classic.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 15 (AP)--Slipping through a narrow opening on the rail, the A.C.C. Stable's Sun Egret carried 122 pounds to a decisive victory in the twenty-eighth Harford Handicap today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15--Representative Ralph O. Brewster of Maine said to the Republican women of Pennsylvania today that "the more time we spend in hating Roosevelt the less time we have for selling our goods."

In person and by mail hundreds of thousands of taxpayers filed their State income tax returns yesterday. The local and Albany offices of the State Department of Taxation and Finance were crowded with persons who had waited until the

Rumors that Italy's status as a neutral may be altered shortly and that the treatment of her ships by the Allied blockade may undergo a change were reported responsible yesterday for a move by underwriters doubling the marine war risk insurance rate for goods carried to the Mediterranean in Italian ships.

Heavy rains and snowstorms this month have poured billions of gallons of water into New York City's reservoirs in Westchester and further upstate bringing the supply up to a point where there is no longer any danger of a water shortage in

The report of the Electric AutoLite Company for the first quarter of this year indicated a net profit of $2,485,280, after all charges, equal to $2.08 each on the 1,197,192 shares of stock outstanding. In the March quarter a year ago, the net profit was $1,620,903 or $1.35 a share.

ALBANY, April 15--Governor Lehman signed today the Todd bill allowing nurses another year before they must have licenses to practice their profession in this State. A bill passed last year, also sponsored by Assemblywoman Jane Todd of ....

The seven-story elevator apartment house at 51 East Sixty-sixth Street has been sold by the Sixtysixth Street Realty Corporation to a subsidiary of Schwarzkopf Lukach, Inc., who announced yesterday that they plan to reduce the size of the present suites, changing the layout into eleven units of two rooms and four of one room.

Although higher temperatures and absence of rainfall improved new crop conditions, reports that considerable replanting had been rendered necessary by last week's freezing weather in the Southwest stiffend prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Communications and transportation facilities have so broken down in Norway that American diplomatic and consular officials are finding it difficult to get in touch with Americans, according to official reports received by the State Department today.

Mayor La Guardia laid the cornerstone for the nearly completed $2,325,000 housing project in South Jamaica, Queens yesterday afternoon and at the same time denounced pari-mutuel betting, introduced in the State at the Jamaica race track, less than two miles away, while he was speaking.

PARIS, April 14--Seldom since mid-October, when the Allies made their strategic withdrawal, has the French front been so agitated--and this despite bad weather with much rain. The salient news today is that scouting parties seeking information have pushed far into German territory beyond the outposts.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)-- Secretary Wallace asked Congress today to make twenty-one "minor modifications" in the farm program, partly to meet complaints that the AAA Act was too restrictive.

Joe DiMaggio, whose habitual absence from the Yankees' line-up on opening day has marked his baseball career as indelibly as have his batting feats, will be following custom today when the Yankees open the American League season against the Athletics at Shibe Park.

United States Attorney John T. Cahill began yesterday the prosecution of charges against Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers and thirty-six of its members. The case is one that was used by Thurman Arnold, head ....

CAIRO, Egypt, April 15--The concentration of the Italian fleet at Bari and Taranto and Giovanni Ansaldo's speech that Italy cannot remain neutral have aroused suspicion here regarding Italy's intentions in the immediate future. It is only suspicion and in no sense fear.
STOCKHOLM, April 15 (AP)--A state of air-raid preparedness was ordered effective at noon tomorrow in Swedish provinces bordering on Norway and in other parts of Southern and Western Sweden.

OTTAWA, April 15--British orders for war munitions to the amount of approximately $25,000,000, including $12,000,000 for shells, will be placed in Canada in the near future, it was learned today. New plants to take care of the munitions part of the orders are already in existence. France also is about to place large contracts in the Dominion, it was stated.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The House opened debate today on the Logan-Walter bill, which is vigorously opposed in New Deal quarters because it proposes to subject decisions and rules of administrative agencies to judicial review.

The Democratic State Committee, in a brief and harmonious meeting yesterday in the National Democratic Club, named the party slate of sixteen delegates at large, each with a half vote, and as many alternates to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

The two eyes owned and operated by this innocent Bystander were fixed on the "tote boards." That was where the money showed up in fancy figures.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15-- Oslo announced today that the pro-Nazi Major Vidkun Quisling had resigned as "Premier" and had been replaced by Ingolf Elser Christensen, for the past eleven years Governor of Oslo Province.

LONDON, April 15--Reports of military and naval exploits in the North should not distract attention from the manoeuvrings elsewhere in Europe, especially southeast of Germany, it was hinted tonight in informed circles.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 15 --A heated debate on the attitude of the Young Women's Christian Associations regarding relations of the United States with warring nations highlighted today's session of the sixteenth biennial convention of the organization here.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Detailed information regarding the new minimum for bituminous coal recommended by trail examiners of the Bituminous Coal Division of the Department of Interior indicate that they are the lowest in the history of government regulation of the coal industry.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Enforcement of its moral and strategic material embargoes by the United States Government is proving a difficult matter in view of the artifices adopted to obtain desired supplies by some of the nations against which the embargoes apply.

Demands of the city of Newark for a guarantee of $135,000 for the use of its airport this year were refused yesterday by four major airlines now operating from La Guardia Field as well as Newark.

In its potential results if it should become law, the Walter-Logan bill, debated in the House yesterday, is the most important single measure considered in the present session of Congress. Its results would be felt for many years to come.

TOKYO, April 15--In discreet but unmistakable language Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita tonight intimated that Japan would oppose any extension of the war in Europe at Netherland India [the Dutch East Indies].

Fourteen school children were injured yesterday when a crowded school bus in which they were being taken home from Rockaway Beach crashed into a guard rail on the South Channel Bridge of Cross Bay Boulevard over Jamaica Bay.

The spread of the war area in Europe is intensifying the desperate need of child refugees, who now flee from one war to find themselves victims of another, according to a survey of conditions in Scandinavia, Central Europe and China announced yesterday by the Children's Crusade for Children.
Battle lines were not yet drawn in Norway yesterday, but the opposing armies were in the field.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Defeat for any attempt to dominate the world by force and engendered hate was predicted by President Roosevelt today, but he warned the PanAmerican republics that they must be prepared "to meet force with force" if a challenge to their peaceful relations were ever made.

The spiritual, patriotic, educational and other ideals for which the University of Notre Dame stands were commemorated by 20,000 Notre Dame alumni last night at the seventeenth annual observance of Universal Notre Dame Night.

The Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Church, was elected Moderator of the Presbytery of New York yesterday at the annual meeting of the Presbyterian body in the Brick Church, Park Avenue and Ninetyfirst Street.

LONDON, April 15--An enormous increase since the war started in United States trade with Russia through Vladivostok has caused the British Ministry of Economic Warfare to look on all traffic to that port with a jaundiced eye.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 15 (AP)--A brief communique issued tonight after a Cabinet meeting indicated the Government's concern to prevent any internal coup by a possible invader. The Cabinet announced it had examined "political measures taken and considered the situation of foreigners in the country."

BERLIN, April 15--Although events of the last week have concentrated the world's attention upon the extension of the area of combat to Scandinavia the conviction persists in Berlin that the final decision in this war must come on the Western Front and that steps designed to force it will come very soon.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)-- Thomas N. Beavers, head of a drug store chain, told a House Ways and Means subcommittee today that chain stores voluntarily had created market demand for many products newly produced in this country.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15--The brief respite in Balkan nervousness evidenced during the last two days appears to be ended. There are clear indications of growing anxiety.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said today that the government was studying the question of what action to take if the Germans remained in Norway and Denmark and failed to recognize the claims of Americans against assets or credits of those countries.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 15--At least nine persons are known to be dead and thousands of families homeless and many towns in Argentina and Uruguay are in darkness tonight as a result of one of the worst storms that ever swept across the River Plate estuary.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 15--Tonight for the first time since the occupation and the introduction of the blackout a clear moon is shining from starlit skies and some of the blackout's psychic pressure is relieved.

Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Attempts by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers to organize all utility employes on an industrial basis to thwart the C.I.O. drew a declaration of "war" today from another A.F.

The one-story taxpayer containing eleven stores on a plot 75 by 100 feet on the southeast corner of Bryant Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, was sold by the Clay Bryant Corporation to the 984 Realties, Inc., through G. M. Wolkenberg, Inc., brokers in the deal.

The unpredictable Fighting Fox from the Belair Stud of William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, flashed one of his brilliant performances at Jamaica yesterday to win the thirtieth Paumonok Handicap, traditional opening-day feature, as pari-mutuel betting was introduced in New York.

LONDON, April 15--With the announcement of the budget a little more than a week off, the stock markets today were quiet and inclined to weaken despite investment implications concerning the second dollar-securities requisitioning until news of the British landings in Norway caused a renewed hardening.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15-- In the snowy streets of the Arctic seaport of Narvik, where this correspondent saw German troops land and take possession last Tuesday morning, British bluejackets stood today.

GREAT NECK, L. L, April 15-- Edwin Glanffrwd Jenkins, a lawyer with offices at 230 Jericho Turnpike, who had been prominent in Republican politics in Floral Park, died here today at his home, 11 Broadlawn Avenue, after a year's illness, at the age of 41.

TRENTON, N. J., Tuesday, April 16--The State Senate, at 1:30 o'clock this morning, recessed until April 29, to date to which the Assembly had adjourned earlier. Republican leaders, hope that adjournment will be voted then, keeping the Legislature in recess until after the primary election on May 21.

ATHENS, Greece, April 15--A widely accepted view that Germany has been ousted from her pre-war position as Greece's best customer and leading supplier as a result of reciprocal agreements signed recently with the Allied powers appears erroneous.

NEWARK, N. J., April 15--President Roosevelt was requested to revoke the appointment of Myron C. Taylor as "Ambassador to the Vatican" in a resolution adopted this morning by delegates to the eighty-third annual Newark Conference of the Methodist Church.

WASHINGTON, April 16--A luncheon conference today between President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley, "the man behind the ballots" in the Democratic victories in 1932 and 1936, set off new political speculation in the capital.
ST. LOUIS, Aprii 16--J. Russel Sprague, campaign manager for Thomas E. Dewey, announced today that the Dewey forces would enter the Maryland primary, to be held May 6.

Councilman Alfred E. Smith Jr. introduced his first important piece of legislation yesterday when he called for an investigation of Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and the commission itself.

Under cover of a leaden sky and a chilling, graying mist, the Giants made a noble effort to open the National League championship season at the Polo Grounds yesterday in a manner befitting the occasion. But in an unguarded moment they opened it a little too far and that proved disastrous.

A BRASS band played and up went the flag at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Ameri can flag, not the National League pennant. Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, flexing his muscles, tossed out the first ball, which was just a political gesture toward starting the baseball season in this area. King Karl Hubbell, the Old Master of the mound, wafted a strike over the plate and made it official.

EASTON, Pa., April 16--Broader fields for service by privately endowed colleges and universities were pictured here today when 100 or more representatives of sixty colleges attended the annual conference of trustees of colleges and universities.

The ten lots, vacant with the exception of a one-family dwelling, in East 231st Street, running through to East 232d Street, between White Plains and Carpenter Avenues, the Bronx, have been purchased by a client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation and will be improved with two six-story apartment houses. Charles Foster, the seller, has held the property for eighteen years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--One of the original members of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association and one which has missed the big Poughkeepsie race the past several years is heading toward a new season still minus a major objective, such as the Hudson classic.

The labor dispute over "American Jubilee" was successfully mediated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and rehearsals for the $500,000 spectacle were immediately resumed in the late afternoon at the Manhattan Center. Both the World's Fair Corporation and the Actors Equity Association compromised...

Army mechanics dismantled yesterday afternoon the Douglas bomber that made an emergency landing in Coney Island waters at 3:30 A.M. yesterday, with its crew of eight men uninjured. The big plane will be taken to Mitchel Field, L.I., for repairs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16-- Franchot Tone, now appearing in "The Fifth Column" in New York, was signed by Paramount today and will report at the studio late in June for the leading role opposite Madeleine Carroll in "Virginia." Tone's last assignment at Paramount was in 1934 in "Lives of a Bengal Lancer."
Captain Cyril Bentham Falls, military correspondent of The Times, London, spoke last night on a British Broadcasting Corporation news program on the progress of the war in Norway.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Newmont Mining Corporation will be held in Wilmington, Del., on May 6 to vote on a proposal to reduce capital of the company from $8,000,000 to $5,316,460 by the retirement of 268,354 capital shares of $10 par value, but the...

A varied entertainment will feature the annual Spring fete and bazaar of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, which will be held tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Games, sideshows and other attractions are planned for the diversion of children...

The passenger train revenues of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, including mail and express and other revenue, were $13,111,046 in 1939, against $12,810,605 in 1938, a gain of 2.3 per cent, Henry A. Scandrett, trustee in bankruptcy, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

An advance of nearly $1 a bale in new-crop contracts in Liverpool and a further rise in wheat stimulated buying operations on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. A combination of trade and speculative demand pushed the late months into new high ground for the season and left the list with gains of 5 to 16 points.

LONDON, April 16--The sending of money to neutral countries to pay for the transmission of money and parcels of food and clothing into Germany, Poland and Austria is advanced by the British authorities as a reason searching of the United States mails has reached such proportions here.

A centennial exhibition of portraits by John Wesley Jarvis, "the Knickerbocker painter," opens today at the New York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street. Besides the paintings, many of which have been lent for the occasion, a group of...

GREENWICH, Conn., April 16-- There may be a few scattered streams in the southern and eastern sections of Connecticut that are not high and discolored, but if there are we were unable to locate them in a wide swing we made today.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The army and the navy, moved by developments abroad, are calling for a speeding of our defense program. The army wants Congress to vote its full budget request by restoring a cut of about $50,000,000 made by the House and the navy today asked a 25 per cent increase in building plans to create a fleet "second to none."
Hartcourt, Brace has advanced the publication date of John Maynard Keynes's book outlining a radical proposal for the financing of the war. "How to Pay for the War" will be published on April 25.

When an organization of taxpayers in these days finds "much to commend" in any governmental spending program the fact is news. Mayor La Guardia must welcome this pat on the back from the Citizens Budget Commission for his proposed executive budget.

ON THE NORWEGIAN-SWEDISH BORDER, via Stockholm, April 16--The Germans and Norwegians have met in the biggest land fight that has occurred in Norway so far --at Kongsvinger, northeast of Oslo, a few miles from the border station where I am writing this dispatch.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 16 (AP) --Dr. Arthur Davis Variell, who retired from the practice of medicine to pursue research in leprosy, died here today at the age of 7l.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve declared yesterday at the all-college assembly for the installation of undergraduate officers at Barnard College that the vital essence of academic freedom was the freedom of a professor in his special field to seek for and to teach truth as he sees it, and that this must be preserved, with sacrifice if necessary.

Restaurants, textile and clothing firms and advertising agencies figured in many of the leases of commercial space reported in Manhattan yesterday. Several music publishers also took larger space in Broadway.

BOSTON, April 16--The Durocher boys are off in front! Thanks to the five-hit pitching of John Whitlow Wyatt, Brooklyn's crippled ace, and the timely hitting of Dolf Camilli, the Dodgers took the opener from the Bees today, 5--0, beating Sailor Bill Posedel and erasing Casey Stengel's smile.

Great activity marked all fronts of the second edition of the World's Fair yesterday as hundreds of workers painted and revised small and large exhibits in time for the opening on May 11 and crews of gardeners landscaped large areas of the 1,216-acre exposition site.

In landing the vanguard of an army at or near Narvik, the British Navy has completed a carefully planned operation which deserves to rank in skill with the battle against the Graf Spee. It seems to have combined daring with precise preparations--and without preparations, down to the smallest detail...

The Grace liner Santa Clara returned here yesterday from the west coast of South America and the Moore-McCormack cargo liner Donald McKay arrived from the east coast. The latter made the trip in record time.

PARIS, April 16--On the Western Front today the Germans turned their attention to the British and made an attack in a sector held by them. The action was accompanied by considerable artillery fire, but eventually the enemy was driven back with many casualties. No details of this attack are yet available, nor is its scale indicated.
ALBANY, April 16--Governor Lehman signed today the Dunnigan bill, changing the dates of registration of voters for the Presidential election this Fall to avoid conflict with the Jewish holidays.

LONDON, April 16--Hardly had the Admiralty announced today that for the first time in the war a week had passed without the loss of any British merchantman than word was received that the steamer Stancliffe, formerly the Huncliffe, 4,511 tons, had been torpedoed Friday off the North Scottish coast. It is feared twenty-four members of her crew were lost.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 16 (AP)--Rumania moved to put her Black Sea and Danube ports under navy rule tonight as the first step in an intensive program to prepare the nation for the possibility of war.

Campaign plans to raise money for Jewish refugees and other needy persons abroad were discussed yesterday by the Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees and Overseas Needs, in a meeting attended by 1,000 women at the Hotel Biltmore.

Harold Whitney Mason of Brattleboro yesterday was elected a director of the National Life Insurance Company, Montpelier, Vt., to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation of Charles W. Gammons of Boston. Mr. Mason, vice president and treasurer of the Dunham Brothers...

PHILADELPHIA, April 16-Governor Harold E. Stassen, who in 1938 as a liberal Republican wiped out the decade of Farm-Laborite rule in Minnesota, was selected today to make the keynote speech as temporary chairman of the Republican National Convention to be held here June 24.

The betting total on the second day of Jamaica's race meeting fell to $474,205, but the management nevertheless considered this a highly encouraging sign of the popularity of the pari-mutuel system in view of the unattractive program. In six of the seven races there were odds-on favorites, an occurrence...

The double-bass, known in less refined circles as the bullfiddle, had its moment of glory at the Philadelphia Orchestra's final concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. Eugene Ormandy paid his respects to the slighted but never obscured instrument by conducting a double-bass concerto by Domenico...
OTTAWA, April 16--A $40,000,000 advantage to Canada on the vital foreign exchange war front is indicated in a ruling by the Foreign Exchange Control Board announced today.

While the approval by the Postoffice Department of pull-out multiple-page units in magazines was hailed generally as an assist to advertising, in actual practice it is proving potentially harmful, according to agency men yesterday. One agency has ordered trade papers to cancel copy for one account...

WASHINGTON, April 16--Some 226 former Chinese factories in Shanghai now are under Japanese control, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly summary of world trade developments. Additional factories for producing soap, glycerin, electric bulbs and candy are projected in the Nantao district.

Max Lippe, Brooklyn bail bondsman, and Dr. Abraham M. Ditchik, Manhattan dentist, both major figures in the inquiry of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen into official corruption in Brooklyn, were sentenced yesterday to terms of hard labor in Sing Sing Prison.

NORFOLK, Va., April 16 (AP)-- Holders of certain securities of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, which has been in receivership for nine years, have informed the Federal District Court here that they will ask that the road be placed in bankruptcy.
William Gilman Low of Bristol, R.I., and this city and his daughter, Miss Rhoda Low, who have been staying at the Ambassador, left yesterday to pass a month in Washington.

BRUSSELS, Belgum, April 16-- The only thing that could bring Belgium into the war, said PaulHenri Spaak, Minister of Foreign Affairs, speaking in the Senate today, was that she should have to defend her independence. In that case she would fight, he said, but she is determined to maintain her neutrality policy up to the limit short of that.

Belief that William Gerald Bishop, mystery man of the sedition trial now under way in the Brooklyn Federal court, was the "paid agent of a foreign government" and that he was forming a secret organization "financed by the Germans" was avowed from the fitness stand...
BERLIN, April 16--The Wilhelmstrasse tonight offered a comparatively mild criticism of President Roosevelt's utterances on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of the Pan American Union.

BERLIN, April 16--The German High Command claims a British cruiser was attacked and sunk yesterday by German planes off the Norwegian coast. The name and size of the vessel, however, were not given out.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 16-- Clifford H. Ayres of this place, president of C.H. Ayres, Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., investment banking firm, former executive of New York financial houses and a World War veteran, died yesterday at a nursing home here after a brief illness. His age was 50.

Some civic and realty groups are worried over the possible effects of a bill, approved by the State Legislature and now before Governor Lehman for signature or veto, which is designed to protect a tenant's right to a trial by jury of any legal dispute with his landlord over rent, occupancy or repairs to leased quarters.

As The Old Farmer's Almanac would put it, "about this time look out for keynoters." Yesterday, in fact, the Republican Committee on Arrangements chose this dignitary of its national convention. To Governor Stassen of Minnesota fell the nomination. Young in years, and fresh in point of view, he...

The week of April 29 promises to bring four new attractions to the Broadway scene. In order of arrival they are: April 29, "There Shall Be No Night," at the Alvin; April 30, "Grey Farm," at the Hudson, with Aideen O'Connor and Jane Sterling recently added to the cast;...

The Actors Equity Association, which only yesterday ended peaceably its part in the World's Fair labor row, was plunged into a new controversy last night over its action in barring Equity members from participating in such activities of the Theatre Arts Committee as relate to the campaign for a national theatre.

Fingerprinting of all automobile drivers and restrictions on the size of commercial vehicles were suggested to aid traffic law enforcement, reduce accidents and relieve congestion on streets and highways at the eleventh annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 16--If the House should pass the Walter-Logan bill tomorrow, as its opponents seem to expect, the administration is relying on the Senate to pigeonhole or even to defeat the measure. Since the Senate once put through the bill unanimously, this reliance may seem strange and unfounded.

PARIS, April 16--Paris paid final tribute today to Cardinal Verdier, the capital's twenty-second Archbishop and the 131st successor to St. Denis as religious head of the city. The cardinal died last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The government today acted to protect the National economy from possible adverse effects from the use of the unofficial sterling exchange rate in New York for purposes of collection of duties on exports from Great Britain. The United States now will recognize only the official rate.

Support for amendment of the National Labor Relations Act by Congressional adoption of the Smith bill, now pending in Congress, was approved yesterday by members of the industrial committee and the board of directors of the Merchants Association of New York.

CHICAGO, April 16--Bob Feller of the Indians carved a niche for himself in baseball's hall of fame as the American League season opened today, pitching an amazing no-hit game to defeat the White Sox, 1 to 0, before 14,000 roaring fans.

MONTREAL, April 16--Hardworking and seldom-penalized Bobby Bauer of the Boston Bruins and the veteran Ebbie Goodfellow of the Detroit Red Wings, who has all the qualities needed in a topnotch defenseman, were named today as the winners of two of the National Hockey League's coveted individual prizes.

Teachers' organizations clashed yesterday with the Citizens Budget Commission over education appropriations in Mayor La Guardia's executive budget as public hearings on the budget got under way before the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

CORNWALL, Conn., April 16-- Mrs. Lillias Rumsey Sanford, founder and principal emeritus of the Rumsey Hall School for Boys, died at her home here today in her ninety-first year. She was the widow of Leonard Gibbs Sanford, author and traveler.

PARIS, April 16--"The first great battle between Germany and the Allies has been a naval battle and the Allies have won," declared Premier Paul Reynaud in a short "profit and loss" statement before the Senate, covering the past eight days.

The dollar volume of private construction awards last month in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains was 2 per cent higher than in March, 1939, and the figure for the first quarter also was somewhat higher than for the same...

William F. Fay, one of the city's most famous detectives, who has worked on some of the most spectacular cases in the Police Department's recent history, retired on Monday, it was learned last night. He was the first member of the department to retire as a firstgrade detective under the new retirement system.

Breaking a long-standing tradition against admission of municipal securities to trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the committee on stock list decided yesterday to admit to dealings tomorrow on a "when, as and if issued" basis, 3 per cent Corporate Stock for Transit...

Stockholders of the New York Central Railroad are to vote on the election of three new directors at the annual meeting on May 22. They are George A. Ranney, who will succeed the late James Simpson; Malcolm P. Aldrich, to succeed the late Edward S. Harkness,...

CAIRO, Egypt, April 16--With approval by Parliament within the next few days, a law just written by the Egyptian Cabinet will make espionage or treason against Egypt or its Allies punishable by death. This is one of many measures that the Egyptian Government is now rushing through at top speed.

The election of thirteen of America's successful men under 31 years to the honorary society of the Order of the Rake was made public yesterday by the Young Men of the Advertising Club of New York. One posthumous award is to be made in addition to the thirteen.

The National Christian Action, an organization of Scandinavian churches of all denominations in the city, announced yesterday that the problem of taking care of Scandinavian seamen in this city suddenly had become acute because of the extension of the European war.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16--Congress was asked to enact the AntiLynching and Anti-Poll Tax Bills by the Young Women's Christian Associations of the United States at the close of the sixteenth national biennial convention here today.

A penthouse apartment comprising fifteen rooms in the multi-family dwelling at 1,021 Park Avenue has been leased to Dan P. Caulkins for three years starting Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday. Anne Gugler was the broker.

No decision has been reached as yet on the date for the announced meeting of the Republican delegation to the Republican National Convention, at which the national committeeman and committeewoman from New York State will be selected, Edwin F. Jaeckle, newly elected Republican State Chairman, said yesterday.

DETROIT, April 16--Preparations were completed tonight for tomorrow's election, ordered by the National Labor Relations Board, which will decide whether the C.I.O. or the A.F.L. is to be the collective bargaining agency for the workers in fifty-nine plants of the General Motors Corporation, scattered throughout the country.

A reactionary movement hit the stock market yesterday in the wake of a series of news reports and rumors coupled with some selling from Dutch sources. With facts veiled by a strict wartime censorship it was impossible for Wall Street to determine immediately...

CHICAGO, April 16--War fever gripped the grain trade today and brought in the public as persistent buyers of wheat and corn futures, the price of which advanced around 2 cents a bushel at the extreme, with all deliveries of wheat and July and September corn selling at new seasonal high prices and at the best levels since late in 1937.
WASHINGTON, April 18--Direct diplomatic relations probably will be established in the near future between the United States and Iceland, the State Department announced tonight.

Giles E. Hopkins has been appointed technical director of the United States asbestos division of Rabestos-Manhattan, Inc. He will take up his new responsibilities in the Manheim, Pa., laboratories on May 1.

Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, made public a list of seventeen specific budget cuts aggregating $4,205,677 which he said he would present to the Board of Estimate in City Hall today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16--The Newark Police Department is investigating a report that thirty members of the city force are members of the Christian Front of New Jersey, it was learned today. At the same time, but apparently only as a coincidence, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein assumed charge of the Department of Public Safety.

An issue of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures of the Superior Oil Company will be offered publicly today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. ALBANY, April 16--The City of New York was upheld today in its refusal to grant a license to operate two taxicabs to a former driver for the Terminal Company who said he had purchased them. The Court of Appeals affirmed a lower court's order which had sustained the city's contention that Ephraim Pruzan was not a bona fide taxicab owner.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,853,800 barrels, an increase of 108,800 over the 3,745,000 reported in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Actual production was 303,800 barrels more then the calculation of 3,550,000...

Loss of fruit export markets because of the war has dealt a severe blow to the northern areas of California, but has been offset to a considerable extent by huge airplane orders in the southern section of the State, according to a Pacific Coast merchandising executive who was in the wholesale markets here yesterday.

Scoring its third straight tournament victory, John Adams High's nine took first place in the Queens P.S.A.L. race yesterday by beating Cleveland, 4 to 3, at Melvina Stadium. Newtown, which had won both of its previous league starts, played a 5-all tie with Flushing at Memorial Field.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16 --German invaders today sped a Nazi-packed troop train through Norwegian-held territory, past the very muzzles of a Norwegian-manned fortress to push within three miles of the Swedish border.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn announced last night that he was seeking to link the Brooklyn murder syndicate with the slaying in 1937 of Harry Millman, one of the last leaders of Detroit's notorious Purple Gang, who was shot down in a bar before sixty Thanksgiving Eve merrymakers...

Academic freedom has grown to such an extent that it has injured academic decency, while the Bill of Rights has gone to seed, Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the National Committee for Religious Recovery at the Murray Hill Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The number of German troops in Norway is said to be much smaller than has been reported, according to information on German military operations reaching some officials in Washington.
TOKYO, April 16--Japanese attention is now focused on American reactions to the statement of Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita that Japan would oppose any change in the status quo in the Far East.

Storage of an undisclosed amount of Norwegian whale oil at warehouses in New Orleans by Great Britain to keep it out of war zones was reported here yesterday. A larger amount of oil is still in Norway, and some has reached British ports, according to information in this market.

LONDON, April 16--Although the approaching budget further restricted business, the tone of the stock markets today generally was firm.

Within the next month the Pennsylvania Railroad plans to institute a system at its station here under which travelers will pay a fixed fee of ten cents for each article of luggage carried by porters, it became known yesterday.

Decision of the United States Treasury to adopt the British Government's "official" rate on the pound sterling, instead of the much lower free-market rate, in computing customs duties on imports of British Empire goods is viewed as a move to prevent excessive imports ports of competitive goods.

Contributions from business concerns and employee groups to the Greater New York Fund for the support of 393 voluntary welfare and health agencies total $1,320,408 to date, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor attended by voluntary campaign leaders and associate workers.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16--A seventeen-hit attack that included four homers and three doubles gave the Newark Bears a 17--2 victory over Princeton in an exhibition game on University Field today.

The quiet round-up of a vice ring which, it was charged, preyed on girls in a Brooklyn high school was revealed yesterday evening by the arrest of two men in a photograph studio at 145 West Forty-fifth Street and their interrogation in the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

Mrs. Alice Maud Allen Lombard, widow of Louis Lombard, musician and financier, died here Sunday, according to an announcement made last night by her son-in-law, Thomas Allen 3d, lawyer, of 511 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)--A witness before the Senate Banking Subcommittee urged today that proposed legislation to regulate investment trusts be sent back to the Securities and Exchange Commission, where it originated, for redrafting in collaboration with members of the industry.

Contracts for the first large-scale orders of American-made warplanes by France and England since the outbreak of the European war last September probably will be signed here before the end of the week, it became known yesterday.

Director's of the American Locomotive Company will consider the resumption of dividends at a meeting this month, William C. Dickerman, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. WASHINGTON, April 16--Preston S. Arkwright, president of the Georgia Power Company, charged the New Deal today with attempting to "smear" public utilities and Senator George, of Georgia, who defeated the New Deal candidate for the nomination for Senator in the purge "primary" of 1938.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation made public today on a State basis the information on condition of operating insured banks on Dec. 30 which it recently announced on a nation-wide basis.
MOSCOW, April 16--The newspaper Izvestia calls attention to the unsatisfactory position of the year's Spring sowing.

Counsel for Local 807 of the Teamsters Union and thirty-six individual defendants yesterday sketched in a background against which they asked a jury in Federal Court to consider any charges that may be made against them at their trial on charges of violating the Anti-trust and Anti-rackateering Laws.

LONDON, April 16--The Norwegian Minister, Erik Colban, called at No. 10 Downing Street today and urged Prime Minister Chamberlain to send Allied troops immediately against the Germans in South Norway where, he said, help is "urgently needed."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16-- The Swedish Government today placed an embargo on the sale of fuel oil and closed more ports to shipping, while gas companies, to save coal, proposed to shut off gas from all homes where wood fires are available.

Kansas shows signs of returning to the Republican fold, after having gone Democratic in 1936, according to the results of a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion, made public yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, its director.

Fighting before 5,350 fans, the largest crowd this season, at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, Lenny Mancini of Brownsville gained an eight-round verdict over Joey Fontana of Bensonhurst last night. Mancini weighed 135 pounds, and Fontana 134 .

The war in Scandinavia and its threatened effect on organized shipping services throughout the world were felt here yesterday when ship operators in the Far East Conference ordered rate increases as high as 50 per cent on general cargo items moving between Atlantic ports and the Orient.

ROME, April 16--A group of 300 agricultural workers left today for Germany, where they will be employed in seasonal work. This is only a fraction of a large number, estimated at 25,000 to 30,000, scheduled to leave Italy in the next few days.

WASHINGTON, April 16--President Roosevelt and Robert Moses Grove did the pitching that opened the American League baseball season here today in a game that gave the Boston Red Sox a 1-to-0 victory over the Washington Senators.

Portland H. Sullivan, who is known to radio listeners by her maiden name, Portland Hoffa, the wife of Fred Allen, yesterday appeared as the purchaser of a Washington Heights apartment property in a deed filed with the register's office.

Mrs. Edith Graham Mayo of Rochester, Minn., widow of the famous surgeon, Dr. Charles H. Mayo, who founded the Mayo Clinic, was selected yesterday by the American Mothers' Committee of the Golden Rule Foundation as "The American Mother for 1940."

John J. McGloon testified in Federal court yesterday that the volume of reports passing over his desk as controller of McKesson Robbins was too great to check up. During the decade while F. ALBANY, April 16--The Court of Appeals today reversed lower-court orders which had Granted motions of Floyd L. Carlisle and others to dismiss the complaint of Otto Frank, who sought to transfer 200,000 shares of the Northeastern Power Corporation.

ALBANY, April 16--The Court of Appeals today rejected the motion of Hulon Capshaw for leave to appeal his removal as a New York City magistrate by the Appellate Division.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 (AP)--Informed government sources said today that Mexican secret police had evidence of under-cover activities of Nazi and Communist agents seeking to foment an uprising to divert American nations, particularly the United States, from any move to enter the European conflict.

WASHINGTON, April 16--A bill to create nine new Federal judgeships, three for the Circuit Courts of Appeal and six for District benches, was passed by the Senate today, 47 to 21, after defeat of amendments by Senator Reed, Kansas Republican, to strike out all the authorizations.

WASHINGTON, April 16--United States exports in March were valued at $344,000,000, about 2 per cent above the February figure of $338,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. The March estimate was based on preliminary figures.

Conscientious New Yorkers can now take a drink from the water tap without feeling guilty. For suburbanites there will be plenty of water to sprinkle lawns. The Department of Water Supply reports that our shortage is ended, for this year at least.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)-- Mrs. William H. Becker of Summit, N.J., honorary president general of the Daughters of the American Revolution, declared today that "the most vital need of our country and of the nations of the world is a moral and spiritual revival."

Finally under way in full force, the college baseball campaign has begun to assume perspective. Roberts of the United States Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, April 29--After spending half a century studying the health of old persons, Dr. Jean Besancon, 80 years old, presented the following formula for longevity today: Don't drink water, take as little exercise as possible and have an afternoon highball instead of tea.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 29 (AP) --Two horses from the stable of W.F. Mannagh triumphed at Narragansett Park today, Bill Bee winning the fifth race and Milk Punch taking the featured Scituate Purse.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., April 29 (UP)--The British 8,000-ton cruiser Caradoc arrived at Los Angeles Harbor today to take on fuel. Guards were posted around the dock. Under the Neutrality Laws of the United States the vessel has twenty-four hours to refuel and leave port.

WASHINGTON, April 29--Forged material or any type of publication tending to incite racial or religious hatred would be barred from the mails, even though it were inserted in the Congressional Record, under the terms of a bill introduced today by Senator Barbour.

BERLIN, April 28--Dr. Robert Ley, chief of the German Labor Front and new Nazi party philosopher, in his broadcast to German youth this morning gave the National Socialist definition of freedom and indicated what German leaders hope to gain from this war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 29 (UP)--An Oslo dispatch to the newspaper Allehanda said gasoline restrictions imposed by the Germans today in all occupied Norwegian territory had ended private automobile traffic and that only carts were seen on the roads .
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 (AP)-- Jack Dempsey, former world heavyweight boxing champion, will be on the spot Friday night for the first time in his career as a referee.

Glore, Forgan Co., as managers of the underwriting group for the offering of Marshall Field Co. preferred stock made yesterday morning, annourced that the books were closed at noon with a heavy oversubscription. The stock was priced at $104 a share and accrued dividends.

John H. Ball and Seymour Milstein, juniors in the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science, have been elected co-captains of the university's varsity debating team for the 1940-41 academic year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. E. Thayer Curry of the department of public speaking and coach of the squad.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer formally to the public today a new issue of $81,602,000 Union Pacific Railroad Company refunding mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series A, to be dated June l, 1940. The bonds, which will mature on June 7, 1980, will be priced at 102 and accrued interest.

WASHINGTON, April 29--The Yanks must have reached the turning point today at Griffith Stadium. They checked their three-game losing streak by halting Bucky Harris's Senators, who had scored five straight victories. The count was 5 to 4.

A new $1,000,000 elementary school for the Bronx, designed to provide community facilities within a small neighborhood building, is to be constructed by the Board of Education, Daniel P. Higgins, chairman of the board's buildings and sites committee, announced yesterday.

The Prints Division of the New York Public Library has arranged and installed its 250th exhibition. The work selected, hung in the Print Gallery (Room 321 on the third floor), will be placed on public view tomorrow, and the show is to be current until next December.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP)-- Two home runs each by Hal Trosky and Ken Keltner sparked the Indians to a 10-to-5 victory over Philadelphia today before a crowd of 2,500. The victory gave Cleveland undisputed possession of first place in the American League race.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 30-- Frank R. Chambers, chairman of the board of directors of Rogers Peet Company and a member of the company for sixty-five years, died today at his home here after a short illness. He was 89.
Plans were filed yesterday for a two-story private dwelling to be erected at a cost of $20,000 at 17 East Sixty-fifth Street for the Mills Land Corporation.
CHICAGO, April 30--Prices of wheat turned downward today after a showing of strength in the early trading. Hedging pressure was light.

Dewey for the Republican Presidential nomination, developments between now and the actual calling of the roll at the Philadelphia convention are expected to decide for whom Tennessee's eighteen votes will be cast.
ST. LOUIS, May 2--Finally swinging into action, and swinging with considerable fervor, the Giants flattened the Cardinals today. The score was 7 to 4.

The World's Fair (1940) people are sticking grimly to the new "Peace and Freedom" theme which they have substituted for the Buck Rogers or Whalen "World of Tomorrow" theme. The delicate ear, however, detects a martial note in the new name for the information booths. This year they're called "pillboxes."

BERLIN, May 2--British naval units approaching Norway's west coast yesterday were seriously damaged by German bombers, it was reported here tonight. Two aircraft carriers and a destroyer were hit, it was claimed, and one of the aircraft carriers was seen to be afire.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Participations in the forty-three underwritten securities issues registered under the Securities Act and offered for sale in the first quarter of the current year aggregated $365,533,000, the Securites and Exchange Commission announced today.
End-of-the-month factors figured in the small decline in excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday, official data yesterday showed.

CHICAGO, May 2--Wheat futures declined cent a bushel early today on the Board of Trade to the lowest level since April 8 under pressure of local selling and moderate, liquidation. However, there was little selling on stop-loss orders, and later when shorts started to ...

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, resumed active participation in the affairs of the National Republican Club last night after an absence of more than two years.

Despite a reluctance to oppose the State of New Jersey in its application for abolition of free lighterage, the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce believes that a successful culmination of the action would ...

Executives who learn by their own experience alone and who neglect to keep step with current events in other fields were blamed for the present plight of industry in an address by Merritt Lum before the Industrial Relations Section of the Society for the Advancement of Management in The Builders Club last night.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Securities and Exchange Commission disapproved today a plan for reorganization for the Island Power and Light Corporation and the Commonwealth Light and Power Company, condemning "the frenzied trading" of utilities securities by promoters which, it alleged, resulted in formation of the two companies.

ANALOMINK, Pa., May 2--The last time we defied the prophecies of the weather man we found it was a mistake. Yesterday we depended on the "light showers" prophecy and found he hadn't taken in enough territory, for we arrived at Analomink last night in what would best be described as a downpour.

Despite troubled world conditions, the American people can still maintain faith and optimism in the eventual outlawing of war by an active public opinion, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--A Senate-House conference committee agreed today on a Rivers and Harbors Bill authorizing expenditures of $110,035,450. Before doing so, however, it struck out a $34,509,000 project for East River Harbor, off New York City.

Nineteen of the 122 persons indicted on bootelegging charges last week pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, while seventy-three others, including most of the alleged ringleaders, denied any guilt. All who pleaded were released in bail, set by Judge Edward A. Conger.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 2-- The Ahto, a sailing craft about as big as one of the Queen Mary's lifeboats, deposited a load of roundthe-world travelers here today, including 2-year-old Teddy Walter, son of the skipper.

Boston, Mass., will enter the market soon with an issue of between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000, it was reported in bond circles yesterday. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will be used for various purposes, including welfare, funding and subway. Details of the offering have not been disclosed.
Resale of a blockfront that had been acquired at foreclosure about a year ago featured a large volume of realty activity in the Washington Heights area yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The House today brought the Norton Wages and Hours Act amendments into position for a final vote tomorrow after adopting changes demanded by segments of business.

A low-cost housing project in Suffolk County will be undertaken by Causeway Estates, Inc., operator and builder, of Merrick, which has purchased seventy acres just north of the railroad station in Islip.

LOUISVILLE, May 2--Mioland, the colt from the Golden West, hailed by some as the mystery horse to upset Bimelech, today had his final workout through mud for Saturday's sixty-sixth Kentucky Derby as thousands of visitors shiv-...

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 2-- --Wrecks of approximately thirty naval and merchant ships in the only part of Narvik Harbor shallow enough for anchorage have ruined it as a port, four captains of British merchant ships agreed today.

Clean and wholesome entertainment will mark the second edition of the World's Fair, Mayor La Guardia told fifty business men who gathered at City Hall yesterday to discuss plans for popularizing the spectacle this year.

As a result of a sharp drop at New York together with smaller declines at some of the other reporting centers, the volume of bank clearings for the latest week fell below the comparable 1939 period for the first time in five weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Only three Senators dissented today from overwhelming action by the Senate overriding a veto by President Roosevelt of a grant for the benefit of a special group of veterans of the Philippine insurrection.

Since they have had better weather and are far more advanced in general condition, the Far West's athletes dominate the monthly tabulation of American track and field performances made by the A. A. U. in its official publication, The Amateur Athlete, the May issue of which came off the press yesterday.

Norman Zeff, a gangster hold-up man, died in St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers yesterday of bullet wounds from the pistols of three policemen. As he lay dying he told how he had murdered two policemen and wounded a third, while other evidence linked him indirectly with the murder of still another policeman.

In a school system as large as New York's it is not greatly surprising that an average of twenty-five anonymous letters reach the Superintendent's office weekly.

Consolidation of virtually every city medical service into a new department of medical care was urged yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Hospitals Commissioner, in a report to Mayor La Guardia outlining the problems confronting his department.

Miss Mary Nell Porter, Memphis, Tenn., debutante, who was selected for the role of "Maid of Cotton" by the National Cotton Council and the cotton exchanges of New York, Memphis and New Orleans, arrived yesterday for a four-day visit designed to promote interest in American cotton.
LONDON, May 2--The pressure on investment money again enabled gilt-edged securities to make the best showing in today's stock markets.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The foreign policy of the United States is Governed by a desire to remain at peace, Breckinridge Long, assistant secretary of State, said in an address before the Forum on Foreign Policy and National Defense at the National Institute of Government in the auditorium of the Labor Department tonight.

Receiving the report of a twoyear study of the prevalence of crippled children in the city and existing means for their care, Mayor La Guardia ridiculed yesterday the idea that the Federal Government was paternalistic and held it the duty of government to pro vide public health facilities.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 2--The general conference of the Methodist Church adopted a report today urging President Roosevelt to recall Myron C. Taylor as his personal envoy to the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, May 2--President Roosevelt indicated sympathy for Southern shippers in their fight for revision of freight rate differentials favoring Northern ports today when he nominated J. Monroe Johnson, assistant secretary of commerce,...

Plans for a new $600,000 Catholic church and parochial school at the southwest corner of Olmstead and Benedict Avenues, in the Parkchester section of the Bronx, were announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York. It will be known as the Church of St. Helena.
A number of residential properties and two parcels of vacant land in various Westchester County communities were among the sales reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Plans for the largest peacetime field exercises ever held by the army have been tentatively completed by the War Department for this Summer and now await final action by Congress on the necessary appropriations, it was learned today.

The largest Republican gains since 1936 have taken place in Middle Western States recently, according to the results of a survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion, Dr. George Gallup, its director, revealed yesterday.

Stores to serve families in the new municipal housing project at First Avenue and 105th Street will be erected at the northwest corner of those two thoroughfares, directly opposite the housing site.

Poland will annex at the 1940 World's Fair the section in the Hall of Nations occupied last year by Soviet Russia, one of the nations that is occupying the homeland of the wrecked Polish Republic, Baron Stefen de Ropp, Commissioner General from the exiled Polish Government at Angers, France, announced yesterday.

Significant music of three centuries figured on the program given last night by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, at its final Thursday evening concert of the season. The eighteenth century was represented by Handel's concerto grosso in B flat major, Op. 6, No. 7; the nineteenth century by Mendelssohn's "Italian" symphony, and the twentieth by the Second symphony of Sibelius.

The budget deficit of the United States and its foreign policy held the attention of the National League of Women Voters at its convention meeting yesterday, the first presented in opposing views by two speakers, the second in lively discussion among the delegates.
The weather man has been rougher on major league baseball teams this year than either Tex Carleton or Bobby Feller in the middle of a no-hitter.
The flowering cherry trees in the city's parks and along some of its parkways finally bloomed yesterday, ten to fourteen days late because of the lack of sunshine this Spring.

PARIS, April 19--For many seasons English woolens have had considerable influence on Paris sports and tailored styles. This is more than ever apparent, now that the Allies are so closely collaborating in the fashion field, as well as in martial and political matters. Therefore the recent exhibition of British woolens available for export is arousing much interest in Paris, as well as London.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 2--Britain's decision to divert shipping from the Mediterranean increases the belief that Egypt may soon be involved in the war. Precautionary measures, such as the guarding of all communication lines, were immediately taken.

Sanford Bates, executive director of the Boys Clubs of America, speaking yesterday afternoon at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, urged adults to enter into a "partnership" with youth as a means of cutting juvenile delinquency and building better citizens.

The long fight of the George F. Getty interests to get control of the management of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company apparently has ended. This was disclosed yesterday by William F. Humphrey, president of Tide Water Associated,...

LONDON, May 2--In a speech before a critical House of Commons today Prime Minister Chamberlain slightly lifted the veil on the events that have taken place in Norway since the Germans invaded that almost defenseless country and the Allies undertook the task of dislodging them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2-- Jean Arthur's next vehicle at Columbia will be "New Orleans," an uncompleted novel by Louis Bromfield which the studio purchased in outline form for $50,000. George Stevens, formerly of RKO, has been signed by the studio to a term producer-director contract, and "New...

BALTIMORE, May 2 (AP)--Blensign, an untried son of Blenheim and Design, made his first start a highly successful one at Pimlico today as he accounted for the first running of the Ral Parr Stakes, four-and-a-half-furlong event for 2-year-olds.

Harvey D. Gibson, an old tennis blue at Bowdoin, took time off yesterday from the business of putting the finishing touches on the World's Fair to promulgate plans for the second edition of a tournament that became a popular fixture on the tennis calendar the first year he put his energies behind it.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange here declined yesterday 3 to 14 points on selling by Bombay straddle interests of the distant positions and the releasing of May contracts by spot interests. All of the new crop deliveries except October sold below 10 cents a pound.
SWEDISH--NORWEGIAN BORDER, via Stockholm, May 2--When the Germans claimed the capture of Stoeren two days ago, I decided to telephone to Roeros, the reported location of the German High Command.

CHICAGO, May 2--A new and improved method of transmitting photographs by radio will be put into operation at the Paris office of Press Wireless, Inc., the radio communications subsidiary of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a group of other leading American newspapers, within the next three weeks. This was announced here today by Joseph B. Pierson, president of the organization.

Faced with the prospect of holding physical examinations for 50,000 applicants for city jobs this Summet, Paul M. Brennan, physical examiner for the Municipal Civil Service Commission, resigned his city post yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2--This seat of government today turned a cordial countenance to a friendly invasion by an army of Democratic women who overran its Congressional halls, public buildings and thoroughfares.

Maintaining its brilliant jumping form, the Sixty-first Cavalry Division horse show team last evening won the second phase of the low-score military jumping competition, which was one of the most spectacular numbers on the program of the second day of the squadron A Spring horse show held in the armory on Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street.

PARIS, May 3--In token of the Allies' decision to pursue the war in Northern Norway their troops continue to land in the Narvik sector and further reinforcements are on the way, a military spokesman said today.

RICHMOND, Va., May 3 (AP)--The Newport Corporation, a concern with a capitalization of 300,000 shares, which is authorized to take over and construct shipyards and to build ships, turbines, machinery, automobiles, airplanes, arms, ammunition and other steel products, was chartered by the State Corporation Commission this afternoon. Its home office will be in this city.

Directors of the Boston Edison Company approved yesterday the calling of a special meeting of shareholders for May 28 for the purpose of obtaining approval of a proposal to split the company's capital stock on a four-for-one basis and to reduce the stated value of ...

LONDON, May 3--The abortive effort to retake Trondheim from the Germans with half measures, followed by the retreat of the Allied forces to Narvik, may not lead to the immediate downfall of the Chamberlain Government, but it was apparent tonight that the Cabinet is facing its gravest crisis of this war.

BERLIN, May 3--With the Norwegian campaign already regarded here as history and new actions in other quarters hovering ominously on the political horizon, Chancellor Hitler today launched 6,000 young officers of the army, air force and Elite Guards on their active careers.

WASHINGTON, May 3--President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had intervened personally with Congressional leaders in an effort to obtain more funds for the United States Housing Authority, which he said was doing "an awfully good job."

A new plan of recapitalization for the Curtis Publishing Company was mailed yesterday to stockholders, who have been called to a special meeting in Philadelphia on July 2, at which time the consent of twothirds of the preferred and a majority of the common stock will be required for adoption of the proposal.

This evening's opening is the comedy called "Out From Under," the work of John Walter Kelly and this season's second production by Brock Pemberton. The central character is a Midwestern newspaper editor.
Among the large salaries made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday was that of M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, who received $100,605 in 1939.

TOKYO, May 3--Describing the Japanese jingo outcries for war against Russia or the United States or Britain as "sheer stupid blustering." Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita tonight defended his policy of preserving peace with these countries.

ROEROS, Norway, May 3 (UP)-- Thin Norwegian defense lines crumbled before a furious German onslaught tonight as hammering Nazi motorized legions captured Stoeren, just south of Trondheim. The Germans then advanced rapidly on this town, one of the few remaining centers of Norwegian resistance in Central Norway.
Jacob (Buddy) Baer, younger brother of Max, the former heavyweight champion, knocked Nathan Mann of New Haven out of the heavyweight picture at Madison Square Garden last night.

Five buildings containing forty apartments and three stores at 438442 East Eighteenth Street and 287289 Avenue A, the southwest corner, have been sold by the Street Development Corporation to Morris B. Rettner.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The House killed for this session any legislation to amend the Wages and Hours Act when it voted today, 205 to 175, to recommit the original Labor Committee bill, which had proposed mild changes in the law.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 3--Senator Robert A. Taft, speaking in upState New York for the first time since he became a candidate for the Republican nomination for President, lashed out at government spending for New Deal "propaganda" here today at the opening of a two-day convention of the Advertising Affiliation, composed of advertising club members from thirteen cities in New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Ontario.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M. and 8:45 P.M.; "Rigoletto," presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company, Mecca Auditorium, 8:15 P.M.; Yiddish Culture Society Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; "The Marriage of Figaro," Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, 8:30 P.M.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 3--Two workmen and their employer were killed and another workman was injured in an explosion and fire this morning at the distributing plant of Berg Oils, Inc., in Manor Haven, near here.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The details of the economic foreign policy of the United States as outlined by Summer Welles, Under-Secretary of State, during his European mission, were disclosed by the State Department today through publication of the "complete and accurate text" ...
Competition in the women's annual Long Island interclub team matches got under way at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday, with 140 players taking part in the Class A and Class B contests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 3-- Negotiations are virtually completed for Joan Blondell and Dick Powell to appear together for Paramount in "Transatlantic Clipper," an aeronautical comedy by William H. Wright and John Speaks, the studio announced today.

The Medical Expense Fund of New York, another nonprofit corporation selling insurance against doctors' bills, has received a permit from the State Insurance Department to solicit subscribers, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Superintendent.

PURCHASE, N.Y., May 3--After the second series of interclub matches in the Westchester women's Class A division had been completed over the Century Country Club course today, the 1939 champion, Green Meadow, was tied for first place with the home club team at 11 points.
