STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 3-- Except for their hold in the still snowy wastes around Narvik, Great Britain and France today wrote finis to the Norwegian campaign for the present, when they followed up the evacuation of their southern landing bases by abandoning the Steinkjer line and evacuating Namsos as well.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3--William A. Carr, attorney and widely known collector of Lincolniana, died of a cerebral thrombosis today at his home, 1900 Rittenhouse Square, after an illness of three weeks. He was in his seventy-first year.

Mayor La Guardia directed his fire on the public utility companies yesterday. He asserted that the city as a whole and individuals in it were the victims of a "monopoly" trading on the necessities of life.

A slim, middle-aged woman testified in Federal court yesterday that her operation of a thriving trucking concern and a bus line had resulted in her being locked in the office of Local 807 of the Teamsters Union until she signed a contract.

SUFFERN, N.Y., May 3--A wedding that brought many members of New York society to Suffern this afternoon took place in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, where Miss Marjory Albertine Banks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Scott Banks of New York and Suffern, was married to Uri Balcom Grannis Jr., son of Mr. Grannis of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mrs. Grannis.

Suddenly going berserk, a New York City school teacher attacked a 10-year-old girl pupil in the classroom, defied orders of the Superintendent of Schools to stay away, and later battled three policemen before being subdued and sent to Bellevue Hospital for pyschiatric observation.
April advertising figures were not very impressive and the field as a whole registered only a fractional gain, if any, over the like month of 1939, according to a compilation yesterday.
Conclusions reached as a result of the army's recent Fourth Corps exercises in Georgia coincide with more dreadful lessons taught by the German invasion of Poland and Norway.

LONDON, May 3--By attempting to strike a balance in the naval warfare, Brassey's Naval Annual, published today under the editorship of Rear Admiral H.G. Thursfield, naval correspondent of The Times of London, finds that Britain has maintained her sea power against all German attacks, despite the serious deficiency in the British merchant fleet.
The most interesting racing college crews have seen in the 1940 season will come this afternoon on three waterways that have a long history of rowing.

WASHINGTON, May 3--A struggle to force the Hatch "clean politics" bill out of the House Judiciary Committee, where Chairman Sumners stated earlier this week that it was tabled by majority vote, developed today coincident with a challenge of the count of committee ballots.

The United States liner Washington sails today for Genoa and Naples. Among the passengers are Mrs. D.A. Chaffriax, Randolph C. Wilson, Dr. Joseph Schwartz, Giordano Paltrinieri, William Phillip Simms, Virgil Pinkley, James J. Murphy Jr., United States consul ...

Stephen Paine, who retired as a partner in the brokerage house of Paine, Webber Co., after he had been suspended by the New York Stock Exchange, will be released from Federal prison Wednesday, it was learned yesterday.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday the appointment of the Rev. Dr. John M. Fearns as the new president of St. Joseph's Theological Seminary, Dunwoodie, N.Y., where priests are trained for the Archdiocese of New York.

With virtually no rain in the Cotton Belt, although minimum temperatures over a wide area remained subnormal, pressure on the new crop deliveries depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange here 4 to 10 points yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3--The Securities and Exchange Commission today answered critics who have charged that high registration costs under the Securities Act have impeded the flow of capital to small business by making public the results of a statistical survey which purports to show that in no classification of securities has the cost "reasonably attributable to the SEC" exceeded 1 per cent of the gross proceeds.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Mrs. Charles C. Glover Jr., chairman, and twenty-seven of the eighty-five members of the District of Columbia Advisory Committee for the New York World's Fair, have resigned and several additional members are writing their resignations ...

The successive steps of the British Government in taking over British holdings of American stocks and bonds obviously point to the time when these securities will be needed for payment for American war supplies.

Favored by better weather, retail trade here improved sharply this week. Average department store gains over a year ago were put at 10 to 11 per cent. Consumer apparel demand was the best in a number of weeks, and merchants were inclined to look for sustained activity for some time to come.
Police Captain Max Finkelstein ended his life by a pistol shot early yesterday in his home at 181 Lenox Road, Brooklyn.

Georgetown used the revenge motif in playing Fordham at the Ram field yesterday, since the only Hoya setback in eight games this season was at the hands of the Maroon. So the Washingtonians squared accounts with a 5-to-4 victory to take a 14-to-12 lead in the long-standing series.
The task of national reconstruction that faced the Finnish people on the conclusion of peace with Russia is in many respects more difficult and disheartening than the defense against the invader.

Miss Nancy Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Whitney, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, to Henry Averell Gerry, one of the twin sons of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Gerry of 69 East Seventy-ninth Street and Delhi, N.Y.

An injunction prohibiting picketing of three bakeries in a dispute between two locals affiliated with the same international union was issued in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday by Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer.

The stock market was hard pressed yesterday to place any general interpretation on events abroad. A sharp upward spurt soon after midday gave the list a strong appearance, and although late liquidation reduced some of the gains, the average run of issues held firm.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3--Nine thoroughbreds, one a surprise entry, have been named for the running tomorrow of the sixty-sixth Kentucky Derby, which will see E. R. Bradley's champion colt Bimelech put to the stiffest test of his undefeated career.

As the shadows lengthen this afternoon at Churchill Downs, "Boots and Saddles" will sound for the parade of thoroughbreds to usher in the sixtysixth running of the Kentucky Derby. Louisville is the American melting-pot on Derby day.

Mrs. Anne Harriman Vanderbilt, widow of William K. Vanderbilt, who died on April 20, left her estate in trust to her daughter, Mrs. Margaret Murat Sprague of the Hotel Sherry-Netherland, and three children of her deceased daughter, Mrs. Barbara Rutherfurd.

WASHINGTON, May 3--President Roosevelt lifted the veil that has covered his discussions with Italy by announcing at his press conference today that the United States was striving to prevent the extension of the European war to new areas and other nations.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 3 (AP)-- Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, was authoritatively reported today to have been called urgently to Berlin for a conference with Chancellor Hitler.

A perfect performance on the fifth and final ten-pair string gave Walter S. Beaver of Conshohocken, Pa., the national doubles trapshooting crown for the fourth time at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island traps yesterday.

The League of Women Voters, ending its biennial convention yesterday, re-elected Miss Marguerite M. Wells of Minneapolis president, adopted planks to be submitted to the political conventions and mapped out a program for its own members in sessions at the Hotel Commodore.

NORTHERN NORWAY, May 3-- Twenty-four hours after Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's declaration in the House of Commons that the Allies were retreating from Southern and Central Norway and following their embarkation from Namsos, the Steinkjer front has capitulated.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Now that the Allies have yielded almost all Norway to the Germans and the Norwegian Army command is talking of negotiating a truce, it is believed in Washington that the British will take over the Norwegian fleet as they have been taking over ...

In the absence of any large taxexempt bond issues on the schedule for early offering, municipal bond men turned yesterday to discussion of a possible entrance into the longterm bond market by Controller Morris S. Tremaine of New York State.

Greater New York Fund Sunday will be observed tomorrow in the churches and today in the synagogues of the city. Pastors also will ask that interest be taken in the seventeenth National Music Week, which begins tomorrow.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, widow of the financier and philanthropist, has leased a duplex suite covering two floors in the apartment house at 1070 Fifth Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents, and Warrent Marks Assosiates, brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Jesus Silva Herzog, general manager of the Mexican Petroleum Distribution Agency, announced tonight the conclusion of three contracts with United States oil companies for the sale of $54,000,000 worth of petroleum and petroleum products.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3--Raids last month by agents of the Dies committee and Philadelphia police upon local headquarters of the Communist party and the International Workers Order were ruled illegal today by Federal Judge George A. Welsh.

Forty-one children from 6 to 15 years old will receive medals and honorable mention ribbons today at the closing concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's Carnegie Hall series of Young People's Concerts.

As a documentary film of the trials and tribulations of Hollywood neophytes, "Star Dust," which opened yesterday at the Roxy, is unlikely to stem the westward migration of youngsters with hallucinations of swimming pools and a six-figure apotheosis to stardom.

The reign which the women fencers of the Salle d'Armes Vince enjoyed as the national team champions for the last decade came to an end last night. Capturing the title by a slim margin of one bout, the Salle Santelli outfit defeated the Vince representatives at the Fencers Club by 5--4.

The abolition of free lighterage in the Port of New York would be harmful to the port's international trade and injurious to the industries and commercial houses in the territory of Paterson, N.J., witnesses testified yesterday before the Interstate Commerce Commission hearing in the New Jersey lighterage case at the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

A CHARACTER in "Private Lives"--as we remember it--was asking a laconic traveler about his impressions of the Far East. "China?" "Very big, China," was the answer. "And Japan?" "Very small." The great size of China stands out in Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's new book.

THERE'S a touch of magic somewhere in the Churchill Downs set-up and the Kentucky Derby. Maybe it's the blue grass that does it. Or it could be jolly old Colonel Matt Winn, who waved the magic wand over the scene long ago.

WASHINGTON, May 3--Roundlot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 13 was 7,544,090 shares, compared with 8,027,590 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

MOSCOW, May 3--Russia and Germany have a common interest in preserving Swedish neutrality, their representatives agreed at a conference here two weeks ago, it was announced tonight by Tass, official Soviet news agency.

ROME, May 3--While the press was crowing over the Allied withdrawal from Norway and casting aspersions over Britain's military prowess, United States Ambassador William Phillips showed a certain degree of optimism by leaving this afternoon for Florence "to rest over the week-end."

The American freighter Flying Fish returned safely yesterday from the war-torn port of Bergen, Norway, bearing the marks of British machine-gun bullets on her foredeck and, in the words of her officers and crew, graphic accounts of fourteen harrowing days spent at the port while the British and Germans engaged in a one-sided struggle for domination of the area.

Jacob Shongut of New Rochelle, N.Y., long an auctioneer here and the last coroner of the Bronx, died on Tuesday at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was born in Evansville, Ind., sixtyseven years ago.

Johnny Longden, in recent years among the nation's top-flight riders, got three winners at Jamaica yesterday and just missed another in the featured Delft Purse. The Delft, a six-furlong dash for 3-year-old fillies, went to the Sting filly, Ouch, piloted by Alfred Robertson, with Longden second, aboard Boola Brook. Jessie Gladys was third. A crowd of 10,432 attended.

By outspoken declarations and by indirect appeals to belligerent nations and neutrals through accredited representatives President Roosevelt has attempted repeatedly to prevail upon belligerent nations to negotiate for peace, or, failing that, to prevent the war from spreading.

LONDON, May 8--Viscount Halffax, Foreign Secretary, talked today with Ivan Maisky, the Soviet Ambassador. They had what was described here as an "affable conversation" over the proposed AngloRussian trade talks.
BOSTON, May 8 (AP)--The stouthearted relief pitching of Jack Wilson enabled the Red Sox to increase their American League lead today by defeating the Tigers, 5--4.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Dominion of Canada will emerge from the war, particularly if it is a long conflict, "economically stronger than ever in her history," F.J. Horning, economist of the Royal Bank of Canada, testified today.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 8--Miss Janet Macfarlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Macfarlan of Ridgewood, has completed plans for her marriage to Charles H. Bergmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph C. Bergmann of New York and Falmouth, Mass., which will take place here the afternoon of June 7 in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

CHICAGO, May 8--In marked contrast to the Summer heat of St. Louis, the Dodgers ran into cold, dismal and rainy weather here and for the fourth time on this short Western invasion suffered a postponement today.
HOLLYWOOD, May 8--Mildred Natwick was engaged today by John Ford for the leading feminine role in Eugene O'Neill's "The Long Voyage Home," which is before the cameras at Walter Wanger's.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Authorization was voted and support pledged for a special Red Cross drive for funds for European war relief, if necessary, at today's closing session of the American National Red Cross convention.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Dr. Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador, said in a statement today that the oil settlement between his government and the Sinclair interests was "a very important factor toward the total solution of the oil problem."

A demand for adoption of some "guarantee" of a continued fivecent fare after transit unification is complete will be made on the Board of Estimate today, when it takes under consideration the request of John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, that it adopt the policy of municipal operation of the unified lines and approve the plan for their maintenance and operation prepared by Mr. Delaney and his associates.

Carlos G. Garcia, 45 years old, a member of a prominent Cuban family, who lost $500,000 in sugar speculation in this city between 1937 and 1939, and defrauded banks and corporations of more than $1,000,000 in a desperate attempt to retrieve his losses, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday for a term of two and one-half to five years.

Fighting broke out among the audience viewing a newsreel picture of Hitler in the Embassy Theatre, 1560 Broadway, near Forty-seventh Street, at 11:15 o'clock last night, when two men booed and shouted invectives at the picture of the Nazi leader.
BERLIN, May 8--The communique of the High Command today said:

LONDON, May 8--The stock markets relapsed today into dullness after a steady opening as a result of the uncertainty regarding the Netherlands situation and news of the Labor party challenging the Chamberlain government.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Pilgrims from the interior report that beyond the sweep from Massachusetts to Virginia which is rimmed by the Alleghenies the American people are at last thinking and talking of the war in Europe more than anything else.

CHICAGO, May 8--The Prohibition party opened its three-day national convention here today with an appeal for a coalition of "Christian and patriotic" forces, and leveled criticism at the New Deal and the two major political parties. The keynote speaker was Claude A. Watson of Los Angeles.

All necessary measures to preserve internal order have been taken by the Netherland Government, but neither the authorities nor the people are at all "jittery," declared Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherland Minister to the United States, at a reception in his honor yesterday afternoon in the library of Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

LONDON, May 8--Replying to strong criticism of the government's conduct of the Norwegian campaign and to suggestions that the Allies should immediately start bombing military objectives inside Germany, Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary, closed the debate in the House of Lords tonight by condemning amateur strategists and defending the government's political and military policies.

Mrs. Robert E. Tod gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Among the guests were Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend, Mrs. Morris de Peyster, Mrs. James Brown, Mrs. Philip F. Chew and Mrs. Willard S. Brown.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Senate Judiciary Committee completed its plan today to force a Senate vote on the Logan-Walter bill by agreeing upon a series of relatively minor amendments to the measure, already passed by the House.

WESTFIELD, Mass., May 8--A report that Professor Lewis B. Allyn, one of the two foremost research chemists in this country, refused to disclose a secret formula for a new concentrated food to an agent for a "European power" twenty-four hours before he was murdered in his home here was being investigated tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 8--A proposal of Iowa Democratic leaders that the State convention send its twenty-two delegates to the national convention instructed for Secretary Wallace but carrying with them an endorsement of the Roosevelt administration was received by President Roosevelt today without comment.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (U.P.)--The National Labor Relations Board struck again today at the labor policy of the Ford Motor Company and ordered the company's Buffalo assembly plant to reinstate thirtyeight discharged C.I.O.-United Automobile Workers Union members, with back pay since 1937.

MOSCOW, May 8 (U.P.)--Marshal Semyon Timoshenko, 45-year-old successor to Marshal Klementy Voroshiloff as Soviet Commissar of Defense, was revealed today to have led the Soviet military campaigns in Finland and Poland.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Although wheat flour consumption in the Philippine Islands has declined seasonally, American participation in the flour market there has increased because of a shortage of shipping facilities for Australian and Canadian flour, according to a ...

Twenty-one years ago next month agents for the Lusk committee--how many remember that quixotic organization, which saw a Bolshevik under every bush?--raided the Rand School of Social Science, opened its safe and took away evidence which was expected to prove that Mr. Algernon Lee and his colleagues were planning a violent overthrow of the Government.

Daniel M. Gleason, who is said by the New York City police to be the first member of their department to become a priest, will be ordained on June 24 and will say mass on Sunday, June 30, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, it was revealed yesterday at police headquarters.

DUBLIN, Ireland, May 8--Irish Republican Army "terrorists" who continue their lawless campaign against the Irish Government will receive no quarter from now on, Premier Eamon de Valera asserted in a broadcast to the country tonight.
The Sherman Anti-Trust Law of 1890 is short. Its heart is found in the following words: "Every contract, combination *** or conspiracy, in restraint of trade **** is *** illegal."

The 1939 pamphlet report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., made public yesterday by C.E. Calder, president, shows a consolidated net income of $4,668,023 after all operating expenses, interest and other charges, and after foreign exchange adjustments. In the previous year the profit was $3,935,390.

A NORTHERN BRITISH PORT, May 8--The last units of the British and French expeditionary force that tried in vain to expel the Germans from Southern and Central Norway were safely debarked on British soil today, ending the unhappy history of the first big episode of the war.

ROCHESTER, May 8--The second day of the University of Rochester's "clinic" on New Frontiers in American Life brought to college students a different picture of the attitude of business toward jobseekers than did the first day's session, at which long periods of technical training were described as prime requisites by several American industrial leaders.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Consideration is being given by the securities exchanges outside of New York City to the possibility of an antitrust suit against the New York Stock Exchange on the ground that it is unreasonably restraining interstate trade through its multiple trading rule, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture is considering inaugurating an export subsidy program for corn similar to that used to sell surplus cotton and ...

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday the removal of Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, Communist leader, from its board of directors. The decision was made at an executive session of the board held on Tuesday right at the City Club.

A modification of the treatment of mental disease with insulin shock, in which the deep shock produced by Large doses of insulin is replaced by daily injections of small doses of insulin, has yielded "definite improvement" in 81 per cent of the cases treated, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

The Board of Education appealed yesterday to Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, for a rehearing on the case of Miss Mary B.C. Byrne, a teacher who was suspended for refusing to appear for a physical examination before the board's medical staff.

A group of Summer cottons, whose deigns were based on American themes, was presented to a group of style authorities attending a luncheon yesterday at the Lombardy Hotel. The showing was by Franklin Simon.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday assigned 2,000 patrolmen and officers under Chief Inspector Louis. F. Costuma to the opening of the World's Fair on Saturday.
Mr. and Mrs. Storer G. Decatur left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for their place at Kittery Point, Me.

Trading in the Bronx reported yesterday by brokers wes largely confined to small apartments and other residential buildings. One taxpayer sale was announced, as well as a project for the extension of an existing store building to provide a tenant with more space.

Formal offering of an exchange of $6,239,000 State of South Dakota refunding bonds, Series AA, will be made today to holders of the State's Rural Credit bonds by an underwriting group, managed by Lehman Brothers, First National ...

For the third year in a row, the Sane Santelli team captured the national foils championship at the Fencers Club last night. Jose R. de Capriles, Norman Lewis, Diaz Cetrulo and Albert Axelrod, the last named substituting for Cetrulo in earlier bouts, formed the winning squad that turned back one of the strongest New York Athletic Club teams in that organization's modern history.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8--Columbia made eight hits good for eight runs today and gained undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Princeton, 8-6, on University Field.

A gas pipe and a steam pipe under Fifty-sixth Street exploded early this morning about fifty feet west of Seventh Avenue, releasing a towering wall of steam, filling the area with gas fumes and forcing more than 400 persons to leave the Park Central Hotel on that block.

The Credit Suisse, one of the oldest and largest banks in Switzerland, will formally open its New York agency today in the former Speyer Co. banking house at 24 Pine Street. These quarters will be shared with the Swiss American Corporation, a New York corporation which was organized last July under the auspices of the Credit Suisse to do an investment securities business.

A glance at a sweeping cross-section of American music was afforded a large audience at Mecca Auditorium last night. Folk music, theatre music, concert music and swing wet a encompassed in the course of a long program.

Forest and brush fires, described as the worst in several years, were reported from Long Island and New Jersey yesterday and one of the major blazes was still out of control last night in the vicinity of Westhampton, L.I.

ROME, May 8--Fear that the war would spread to other nations was expressed by Pope Pius this morning in a gloomy and rather bitter address to 4,000 Catholics assembled in the Hall of Benedictions for the customary Wednesday public audience.

Case histories on sixty-two of the most succesful national advertising campaigns in newspapers last year are contained in the 1940 edition of "The Blue Book," issued yesterday by the research and promotion department of the bureau of advertising, A.N.P.A. The campaigns were in sixteen classifications and were directed by thirty-seven agencies.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Architectural League will share eventually in the resiudary income of J. Clawson Mills, 80 years old, interior decorator, of 32 West Ninth Street, who died on April 15.
Alexander Black, author, newspaper editor and expert on photography, died yesterday at his home, 26 West Ninth Street, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.
Peace groups united yesterday to adopt a "peace platform" at the final session of their two-day National Peace Conference at International House.

A margin of only eighty-one votes saved Prime Minister Chamberlain from overthrow in the House of Commons last night on the issue of the conduct of the war in general and the Norwegian campaign in particular.

OESTERSUND, Sweden, May 8 (AP)--German fliers systematically "hunted Norwegian planes like rabbits" and captured twenty-four new undamaged United States-built Curtiss pursuit ships at one field during the conquest of Norway, a 23-year-old Norwegian flying lieutenant asserted today.

Artists of forty-eight States, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands are represented in the two collections of contemporary American art which have been assembled for showing at the New York World's Fair and the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco by the International Business Machines Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

Denying charges by Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace that the American Bankers Association had opposed provisions of the JonesWheeler bill to reorganize the Federal Land Bank System, as part of a campaign to prevent lower interest rates to farmers, a statement ...

TAKING the words out of a reviewer's mouth is usually bad business for an author. There are not unlimited numbers of things that can be said in a limited space about any given book, and the result is likely to be a severe attack of the sulks, reflecting a frustrated soul and a thwarted critical impulse.

BOSTON, May 8--Enlightened governmental policies in regard to railroads make today's rail outlook the most favorable it has been in years, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks was told at the opening of its twenttieth anniversary conference here today.

Harry (Pittsburgh Phil) Strauss, described by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Kings as the most vicious killer in the Brooklyn murder syndicate, has agreed to inform against his underworld associates, it became known yesterday as the prosecutor in a last-minute surprise move obtained a separate trial for Strauss in the ice-pick slaying of George Rudnick, another gangland informer.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Michael J. Quill, president of the C.I.O.'s United Transport Workers Union of America, was forcibly removed from the Dies committee hearing today at a turbulent session in which he accused the committee of "war mongering" and denied that he was a Communist.

Samuel Wiley Wakeman of Quincy, Mass., vice president and director of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in charge of the corporation's shipbuilding activities, died here of a heart attack last night in St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 63.

An affidavit charging that high officials of the German-American Bund had virtually abandoned Fritz Kuhn and "misled" the general membership into believing that their donations would make possible a prompt appeal for the imprisoned bund fuehrer has been filed in Bronx Supreme Court, it was learned yesterday. Kuhn is serving a prison term for embezzling bund funds.

BUFFALO, May 8--"Your organization has a tremendously important role to play in the matter of creating and educating individuals fit to function in a democracy," Mrs. Austin L. Kimball, past president of the national Young Women's Christian Association, told the delegates at the opening of the annual conference of the Hendrick Hudson region of the Girl Scouts.

WASHINGTON, May 8--This is the roll call by which the House voted disapproval of President Roosevelt's reorganization plan which would have shifted the civil Aeronautics Authority to the Commerce Department:

The extra business day last month did not offset active Easter trade a year ago, with the result that the average sales gain of leading chain store organizations in April was cut to 2.4 per cent, the smallest percentage increase in many months, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK

The stock market remained yesterday within its current range, although values in some instances received a slight upward tilt and volume increased. There were, however, no definite movements except in some of the so-called "war brides," which were influenced by indications of more aggressiveness on the part of the Allies.

CHICAGO, May 8--An announcement that the Department of Agriculture was considering inaugurating an export subsidy program in order to dispose of large quantities of corn in Europe kept the price of that grain on the upgrade from start to finish today.
CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)--The Chicago Illinois Midland Railway Company, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Edison Company, announced today completion of arrangements to refund its $6,950,000 of funded debt.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)--The Senate passed and sent to the White House late today legislation suspending existing prohibitions against use of over-age vessels owned by the Maritime Commission.

LONDON, May 8--The first contingent of about 140 volunteers left London today to join the reconstituted Czecho-Slovak Army in France, the ghost of a former army of 2,000,000 men but still an independent unit.

TORONTO, May 8 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs broke loose with a home-run attack on Bill Harris in the early innings to hand the Jersey City Giants a 7-to-3 defeat today and at the same time snap a six-game losing streak.

Dr. Malaku Emmanuel Bayen, once personal physician to Haile Selassie, former Emperor of Ethiopia, and later the deposed monarch's unofficial representative in the United States, died Saturday of lobar pneumonia at Rockland State Hospital.

It is to be regretted that Mexico has seen fit to turn down Secretary Hull's offer to arbitrate the oil dispute. Though it was doubtless within its rights in so doing, the Mexican Government has followed a course which leaves relations with the United States on a decidedly unsatisfactory basis.
BALTIMORE, May 8--Honey Cloud, a former selling plater, capped his rags-to-riches career today with a hard-earned victory in the $20,000 added Dixie Handicap before 12,000 fans at Pimlico.

William J. Wardall, trustee of McKesson Robbins, Inc., announced yesterday that he is negotiating for a settlement of the personal liabilities of the directors of the concern who are also executive officers "not only for payment of ...

Captain John T. Prout Jr. of the 165th Infantry, New York National Guard, and William Gerald Bishop, mystery man of the alleged plot to overthrow the United States Government, both admitted to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation the theft of government ammunition from the 165th Regiment armory, it was disclosed yesterday.
The demand of union sandhogs for increased wages has caused a hitch in plant for building the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, May 8--Webb Miller, general European manager of The United Press, was killed late last night when he fell from a moving train en route to his home at Walton-on-Thames after he had covered the House of Commons war debate.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, May 8--Thirty-seven Jewish refugees from Central Europe arrived here today to put down their roots in a land from which they have received a generous guarantee of freedom and civil and religious equality.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 8-- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, first vice president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, drew shocked murmurs from 400 clubwomen today with the assertion that women inside and outside the federation had told her that if they had the choice they would vote for a dictatorship tomorrow.

CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)--Members of the new board of directors of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad under terms of the reorganization approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal District Court were announced today by Kenneth D. Steere, chairman of the board of the old company.
Mrs. Ralph Pulitzer, widow of the former publisher of The New York World, has leased from Vincent Astor a residential suite in 120 East End Avenue through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., brokers.

Earnings of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation for the first quarter of this year approximated $1,800,000 after all charges, including income taxes, but before depreciation and depletion, E.H. Clark, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday. The profit was equal to $1.63 a share on the capital stock, compared with $1,300,000, or $1.22 a share, for the March quarter a year ago.
Midtown Manhattan was an active center of business leasing yesterday.

When Lefty Al Smith pitched for the Giants a few years back he was a somber and serious citizen. Yesterday, before he took the mound for the Indians against the Yankees at the Stadium, he was as frolicksome as a schoolboy.

Mr. Alexander [A.V. Alexander, former First Lord of the Admiralty] asked me about twenty questions. If I made my speech a catalogue of answers it would hardly be couched in the form the House would expect.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 8 (AP)-- William R. White, State Bank Superintendent, declared tonight that the banker who maintains stability at the cost of losing good-will "exposes the banking business to criticism almost as much as the too liberal banker."

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation on Dec. 31 had $279,128,841, or 56 per cent of its total consolidated assets, invested in properties in Latin America and the United States, Sosthenes Behn, president, disclosed yesterday in his report for 1939. Consolidated assets of the system at the close of the year amounted to $503,674,115.
BERLIN, May 8--The spotlight of German propaganda remained directed today on "the crisis in the Balkans," in spite of alarming reports from the Netherlands.

By a substantial majority yesterday the House of Representatives voted its disapproval of the President's reorganization plan, proposing to change the set-up of the Civil Aeronautics Authority and to abolish the Air Safety Board. If the Senate concurs in this action before June 11 the plan will be annulled.

Controversy developed yesterday over the proposal to renumber buildings on north and south streets in Manhattan and part of the Bronx when conflicting views were expressed at a public hearing in City Hall before the City Council Committee on Parks, Playgrounds and Traffic.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Complaints of excessive campaign expenditures and improper use of State patronage involving both parties in the pre-primary Senatorial races in Ohio have been heard by the Senate Campaign Investigating Committee, Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa, chairman, said today.

COPENHAGEN, German-held Denmark, May 8--In a broadcast over Danish radio stations under the title "Initiative," prominent leaders of trade and other activities, including the general manager of the noted engineering company Kampsax, railway builders, Iran Joergen Saxild, stressed the necessity that Denmark should not give up, but should concentrate on work.

WASHINGTON, May 8--President Roosevelt discussed the Iowa political situation with Senators Herring and Gillette and Representatives Harrington and Jacobsen, the Georgia political situation with Governor Rivers of that State, Clark Howell, Atlanta editor, and James Gillis, chairman of the Georgia Democratic State Central Committee, and transacted other executive business.

The Snider Packing Corporation and its subsidiaries had net earnings of $496,674 in the fiscal year ended on March 31, after depreciation, taxes, interest and other charges, according to a joint statement issued by S.E. Comstock, chairman of the board, and B.C. Olney, president, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The House Appropriations Subcommittee handling the 1941 Relief Bill was reported today to have "tentatively" adopted President Roosevelt's suggestion that the budget-requested sum of $985,000,000 be appropriated in a manner that would permit its use in the first eight months of the new fiscal year instead of having it cover the full fiscal year.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins that his compony had been forced to sell its Tennessee electric utility properties to the ...

The necessity for offsetting losses in export business to European nations, especially the Scandinavian countries, by increasing business in Latin America was emphasized at meetings of two export groups here yesterday. Difficulties in Latin America, however, were admittedly ...
TOKYO, May 8 (U.P.)--Japanese newspapes uniformly charged today that the stationing of the United States fleet in the Honolulu area is aimed against Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Charges that the position of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., which has opposed the Radio Corporation of America in Federal Communications Commission hearings on television standards, "may not be without an impelling motive" were made today in a brief filed by the R.C.A. with the FCC taking exception to the rules and regulations tentatively adopted by the commission for television standards.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Thursday, May 9 (AP)--Authoritative diplomatic quarters said today that Britain and France, pushing a campaign to create a solid southeastern bloc to stand against any German or Italian aggression in the Balkans, had offered a guarantee of Yugoslavia's territorial integrity and independence.

BERWYN, Pa., May 8--Court Time, 8-year-old chestnut gelding, owned by Brooks Parker, won the first leg on the National Hunt Cup at the opening of the Radnor Hunt Club Spring meet today before a colorful turnout of 4,000 spectators.
CINCINNATI, May 8--Getting to Paul Derringer for four runs in the opening stanza, the Bees shelled him from the mound in a five-run fifth inning and went on today to a 10-to-4 rout of the Reds.

Charles Keck, sculptor, whose works include the statue in Times Square of the late Father Duffy, famous wartime Roman Catholic chaplain of the 165th Infantry (old Sixty-ninth), received the Grand Lodge Medal for Distinguished Achievement for 1940 yesterday at the 159th annual convention of the Grand Lodge of free and Accepted Masons in Masonic Hall, 46 West Twenty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, May 8 (AP)--Leo D. Curley and Miss Catherine Sweeney were married on April 29 in St. Mary's Church, Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Robert Beattie, a friend of the bridegroom. Mrs. Edward C. Donnelly, sister of the bridegroom, and Evans Harrington of Boston, a University of Maine student, attended the couple.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Construction of 200 to 300 rural homes at a cost of about $500 each, to house dispossessed tenants and sharecroppers in Southeastern Missouri is to be started soon by the Farm Security Administration, that agency announced today. One contractor already has submitted a bid to turn out these homes in five counties at $499 each, which is the ...
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 8-- The battle for Narvik continued today in spite of snowstorms, with the Allies reporting slow but steady progress.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 8--General Frederick F. Russell, United States Army medical veteran now teaching at Harvard University, received the 1940 George M. Kober Medal at the annual meeting of the Association of American Physicians in Chalfont-Haddon Hall today.

Five graduates of New York University who have been selected as the winners of the 1940 Medallion Alumni Service Awards for "dis tinguished service to the university" will be honored at a dinner tonight at the Faculty Club, 22 Washington Square North.

The strongest improvement in steel orders thus far in 1940 was experienced in the past week, according to The Iron Age, which also emphasizes that the orders have been accompanied by pronounced strength in the principal scrap steel markets. Ingot production has advanced 3 points to 66 per cent, the publication says.

WASHINGTON, May 8--J.P. Morgan has applied to the United States Maritime Commission for approval of the sale of his yacht Corsair to Camper Nicholsons, Ltd., of Hampshire, England, with transfer to British registry, the commission announced today.
Lou Ambers, world lightweight champion, must shed two pounds before the weighing-in ceremonies for his scheduled fifteen-round title bout with Lew Jenkins in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Mayor La Guardia officially opened the annual students' art exhibition at the New York Junior League last evening and presented awards to winners. Creations by pupils of seven private schools and six public high schools in the city were put on view.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The House today rejected, by a vote of 232 to 153, President Roosevelt's Fourth Governmental Reorganization Order by which he proposed to transfer the Civil Aeronautics authority to the Commerce Department and abolish the Air Safety Board.

Laurence Olivier, who last played opposite Katharine Cornell in "No Time for Comedy," and his fiancee, Vivien Leigh, who portrayed Scarlett O'Hara in Gone With the Wind," will appear this evening in the title roles of "Romeo and Juliet" at the Fifty-first Street Theatre, formerly the Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The White House, on authority of President Roosevelt, denied tonight a report from Rome that Mr. Roosevelt had made a peace offer to Premier Mussolini through Ambassador William Phillips in the nature of a feeler suggesting mediation and that it had been rejected.

LONDON, May 8--Six British trawlers--little ships pressed into the navy from their normal fishing tasks--were victims of German aerial attacks during the evacuation of the Trondheim area, the British Admiralty announced tonight.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP)--Stuart Martin hit two home runs today, giving the St. Louis Cardinals nine round-trippers in two days, as the revived Redbirds defeated Philadelphia, 7 to 4. He hit one of the Cardinals' seven homers against Brooklyn yesterday.

With only another week in which to meet obligations of 152,000 bales in the spot month, covering operations increased yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here and the list closed 6 points higher to 2 points lower. The demand for May contracts widened the premium over July to around 32 points as holders of the near delivery released contracts at that difference.

Business, industrial and banking leaders met yesterday in the Union Club at the call of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to hear reports of the progress of the 1940 campaign of the Greater New York Fund and to pledge their continued support to the drive, now flat its half-way mark.

LONDON, May 8--By the slim majority of eighty-one Neville Chamberlain retained the Prime Minister's seals tonight, but for the first time since he assumed office after the coronation of King George VI, nearly three years ago, his regime was in jeopardy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 8-- Moving warily and without provocation but with unmistakable determination to defend her neutrality against all comers, Sweden today made a mine belt 100 miles long to protect all entrances to Stockholm and adjacent ports.

Theories of education should be revised to meet conditions enforced by the war and its aftermath, leaders of education and social service said yesterday at the closing session of the Women's American ORT Convention in the Hotel Astor.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 8--No authoritative explanation of any kind was given today for yesterday's extraordinary military precautions.
The Marlin-Rockwell Corporation, manufacturer of ball bearings, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $719,735 for the quarter ended on March 31.

BERLIN, May 9--A general amprisoners of war with the exception of those serving in the standing army, decreed by Chancellor Hitler tonight, was Interpreted here as a formal declaration that hostilities in Central and Southern Norway had now terminated.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Larger quantities of U-235, the chemical element that was hailed last week as a source of vast quantities of atomic energy, may become avail- ...

Joe Adonis, suave, soft-spoken product of the Brooklyn waterfront area who became one of the nation's leading underworld figures, surrendered yesterday to Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen in Brooklyn and was remanded to jail in default of $75,000 bail fixed on his not guilty plea to two indictments charging kidnapping, extortion and assault.

Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherland Minister to the United States, warning bitterly that bombing in his country could only mean widespread bloodshed, attacked the German invasion of his homeland early this morning as "another act of treachery" on the part of Germany.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 10-- President Roosevelt early today ordered the freezing of all credits held by Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in this country.

Frank E. Gannett, Rochester newspaper publisher, predicted yesterday that his strength at the Republican National Convention as a candidate for the Presidential nomination would be "a surprise to everybody." He characterized as "nonsense" forecasts that there would be a first ballot nomination for District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey or any one else.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Friday, May 10--Queen Wilhelmina said today in a statement on the German invasion of the country that "I and my government will do our duty."

Mayor La Guardia told a group of Queens civic workers who welcomed him yesterday on his first day at the World's Fair City Hall that his Summer sojourn in Queens was far from a vacation for him and his staff.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 9--The frank, hard-hitting speeches during two days of the debate in the British House Commons have done more to enhance respect for Britain in Arab-speaking countries than all propaganda.
PARIS, May 9 (AP)--More than four Norwegian divisions were put out of action in the campaign against Germany, Foreign Minister Halvdan Koht of Norway told newspaper men today.
A business property in midtown Manhattan which had been held in the same ownership for nearly half a century was reported yesterday to have passed into new ownership and then resold.
Triumphing in four of its five matches, the Salle Santelli captured the national p e team championship on its home strips last night.

LONDON, May 9--Webb Miller, European general manager of The United Press, was killed Tuesday night as the result of an accident, Coroner Hervey Wyatt ruled at Battersea Court today. The coroner said he was satisfied Mr. Miller ...

The Friedsam Medal for 1940 was awarded last night to Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York. The presentation was made at a dinner at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.

William Leverich Brower, a retired official of the wholesale drug firm of Schieffelin Co., and for most of his life a leading figure in the religious world, died yesterday morning in Wickersham Hospital of complications attending old age.

Conde Rico, Dream Boat and Grey Wolf were the winners of the featured races at Jamaica yesterday as heavily played choices went down to defeat in all three contests.

The State Labor Relations Board reported yesterday that it had handled more cases in April than in any month since January, 1938. Dr. James Brown Scott, secretary of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace since it was founded in 1910 and director of its division of international law, will retire from those posts July 1 at his own request, it was announced yesterday after the annual meeting of the endowment's trustees in the offices of the Carnegie Corporation, 522 Fifth Avenue.

News Photographer Arthur Menken got to Elverum, Norway, when it was still burning, The flames had been so hot that they burned wet, green timber. They burned the tires off automobiles standing at the curb.

Four charitable institutions share equally in the residuary estate of Mrs. Grace C. Townsend, widow of Dr. Frederick M. Townsend, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court. Mrs. Townsend died April 6.

The steady increase in meat prices in the last few weeks has halted. Pork, which went up most suddenly when the war grew more serious, is less expensive this week and is well below last year's prices. Veal, beef and lamb are unchanged at reasonable prices.

A majority of American voters favors a Presidential candidate who promises to keep us out of war but is willing to give England and France aid in any form short of war, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion reveals, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director.

WASHINGTON, May 10--President Roosevelt's reorganization plan to transform the Civil Aeronautics Authority from an independent agency into a bureau within the Department of Commerce was approved, on a vote of 5 to 3, by the special Senate Committee on Reorganization at the conclusion late today of a two-day series of hearings.

The fall of the Chamberlain Government is more than the end of one man's Premiership. It marks the end of an era. Most of the men who yielded office yesterday, in circumstances of tragedy and horror, had held power with astonishing tenacity for almost nine years.

Selection of a blue-ribbon jury and two alternate jurors for the first trial arising from District Attorney William O'Dwyer's investigation into the Brooklyn murder syndicate was completed at 7:18 last night in Kings County Court before Judge Franklin Taylor. The trial was adjourned until 10 A.M. Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10--An explosion felt over a large part of the Philadelphia area damaged an ammunition packing shed at the Frankford Arsenal tonight, killing one civilian workman and seriously injuring another.

HAVANA, May 10--Joachim Birchenstaedt, a native of Germany, Ecuadorian vice consul to Cuba, was shot and killed by an unknowm assailant in his office-residence in Pinea Street in Vedado suburb this afternoon.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 10 --Bobby Riggs, Wimbledon and national singles champion, defeated George Kraft of New Orleans today in the Tennessee Valley invitation tennis tournament and went into the semi-finals. The score was 7--5, 6--3.

Three more indictments charging labor violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act were returned here yesterday by a Federal grand jury as the result of evidence presented by members of Thurman Arnold's anti-trust division of the Attorney General's office.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman of this city and Arden, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Harriman, to Alexander Clerihew Northrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Norton Northrop of West Roxbury, Mass.

PARIS, May 10--Two hours after the Germans invaded the Low Countries, French and British forces were crossing the border to help the Netherland and Belgian Armies withstand the shock of at least twenty-nine German divisions. Contact was made without delay, and by nightfall the battle had been engaged at many points.

ROME, May 9--The annual report of the Institute for Industrial Reconstruction, through which the State controls fully a quarter of Italian industry, shows increased profits over the successful preceding year. Since most of the great war industries are involved, the gains are high.

A merger of Teachers College's Lincoln and Horace Mann Schools that would preserve both names, retaining the Horace Mann building for elementary grades and the Lincoln building for high school classes, was advocated yesterday by a special committee of five college ...

NEWARK, N.J., May 10--A jury before Federal Judge Thomas Glynn Walker today gave awards totaling S9,000 to seven migratory Negro farm hands in the damage suit they brought against nine young white men accused of beating and otherwise mistreating the Negroes in an effort to drive them out of the State.
A large garage, several tenements, private dwellings, business buildings and a parcel of vacant land in various sections of the city figured in yesterday's Manhattan realty deals.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation and other institutional owners were principals in several of the Brooklyn deals announced yesterday.

Today's events: "Madama Butterfly," 2:30 P.M., and "Il Trovatore." 8:20 P.M., San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; Concert under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of the War Veterans of New York, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M. Eleanor Galison, piano; Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30 P.M.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by sixty municipalities aggregates $82,867,339, of which $60,865,000 con sists of local housing agencies temporary-loan notes. This compares with $72,978,481 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $29,650,312.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Federal Wages and Hours Administrator, today approved recommendations increasing the hourly wage rates of 200,000 employes in the garment and apparel industries. Unofficially it was estimated that this may mean an increase of $10,000,000 a year in wages.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 10 Gloom increases in Southeastern Europe. The surface reaction to the invasion of the Low Countries was relief that war had not yet come here, but there is a realization that this area is almost inevitably the next to be embroiled.
Completing an adjourned game from the tenth round at the Manhattan Chess Club last night, Isaac I. Kashdan still led the field in the United States Chess Federation tournament with a score of 8--2.

STOCKHOLM,, Sweden, May 10 --Sweden, which since the invasion of Norway has not felt safe herself, was shocked today by the sudden attack on three other neutrals who once were associates of Sweden among the Oslo powers. The moral drawn was that neutrality is not enough--for none here accepts the German contention that Belgium and the Netherlands were unneutral--and that Sweden must keep her defense preparations at the high though costly level lately attained.

CHICAGO, May 10--General buying in all grains developed today at the opening of the Board of Trade following the news that Germany had invaded Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg.
Dick Fitzgeratd, basketball captain-elect and the No. 3 pitcher on Coach Jack Coffey's Fordham staff has been getting very little to do this Spring with Gene Bowe and Ed Alex winning regularly.

Mrs. Martin B. Saportas of 151 East Seventy-ninth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Towers, to Lieutenant Herbert Douglas Riley, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Marion Riley of Baltimore and the late Mr. Riley.

MOSCOW, May 10--Industrial defects are pointed out in the newspapers Industria and Machinebuilding. The first complains that despite improvements in many plants there still is a serious lag in fer rous metallurgical plants with a high average of steel spoilage. Plants of the chief administration steel alloy industry lost more than 40,000 tons of metal in the first quarter of this year.

Pete Hanley, St. John's University sophomore southpaw, pitched the Redmen to their eighth triumph of the season yesterday at Dexter Park, defeating Boston College 13 to 2. It was the second victory for Hanley over the Bostonians, whom he set back, 6 to 1, in Boston last Saturday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 10--The German invaders of the Netherlands are being held in check and the surprise element of their attack can be considered a failure, Lieut. Gen. Henri Gerard Winkelman, the Netherland supreme commander, declared tonight.
Lew Jenkins, the skinny kid from Sweetwater, Texas, bombed his way to the lightweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the President, presented yesterday to Mrs. Charles H. Mayo, mother of the head of the famous Rochester, Minn., clinic, a medal honoring her as "The American Mother of 1940."

Judge Marcus B. Campbell dismissed yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn charges of conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government and to steal government munitions against George M. Kelly and Edward L. Walsh, two of the sixteen defendants who have been on trial before him since April 3.
BASLE, Switzerland, May 10 (AP)-- Twehty-seven bombs fell on Switzerland today as foreign warplanes battled over this still neutral country.

ALBANY, May 10 (AP)--The National Consumers Tax Commission announced today to its 228 New York study units that the City of Schenectady had the highest adjusted property tat rate in 1939 and Auburn the lowest among the State's cities with more than 30,000 population.

The Coat Guard cutter Comanche sailed from Pier 18, Clifton, S.I., at 12:25 P.M. yesterday for Greenland. Aboard the cutter, which carried six months' supplies for ship and crew, were James K. Penfield and George L. West Jr., who will be consul and vice consul, respectively, for the United States at Godthaab.
BOSTON, May 10 (AP)--George Salamone, 130, of Boston, and Bob (Poison) Ivy, 129, of Hartford, Conn., boxed a 10-round draw tonight in the Goodwin A.C. feature bout at the Arena.

BERLIN, May 10--For the second time in little more than a quarter of a century the field gray columns of the German Army have been set marching "Nach Paris." Obviously aiming to flank the Maginot Line to stab the Allied armies from the rear the German troops crossed the frontiers into the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg at 5:30
WASHINGTON, May 10--Following is the text of the address by President Roosevelt tonight before the American Scientific Congress:

SINGAPORE, May 10--News of the German invasion of the Netherlands reached the Netherlands Indies by wireless. The Governor General issued a proclamation similar in terms to that of Queen Wilhelmina and announced that all Germans of military age, from 16 upward, would be interned immediately.
CHICAGO, May 10 (AP)--The Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League announced today the purchase of Right Wing Reginald (Pep) Kelly of Toronto.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Within a few hours after Germany's invasion of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, movements started in the administrative and legislative branches of the government for acceleration of the new defense program.

WITH BRITISH EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, in Belgium, May 10 --British troops advanced today to a new battlefront across the Belgian frontier. Ever since the international barriers were raised this morning khaki-clad columns have been moving with smooth efficiency to the east. They met an enthusiastic reception from the Belgian populace. Guns were decorated with flowers and the troops were treated to hurried refreshments as they passed forward.

Even though the 1940 Fair was not officially open yesterday, its foreign area, which felt the shock last Fall of events in Europe, reeled again under news of the sudden invasion of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg and the dropping of bombs in Switzerland by the Nazi war machine.

WASHINGTON, May 10--Department store sales advanced from March to April, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, and the board's seasonally adjusted index rose from 89 to 90 compared with 88 a year ago.

NEWARK, N.J., May 10--Vanity, undefeated 5-year-old bay mare owned by the Fair City Stables of Mrs. L. Victor Weil of Elberon, N.J., tonight gained her second blue ribbon in as many appearances at the third session of the twentieth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory.

ROME, May 10--Italy has not moved today and shows no signs of moving. The great clash of arms has come at last, and Italians consider themselves fortunate as well as skillful diplomats to have kept out of it and to be far away from the scene of battle.

With New York University heavily favored to retain its team ti tle, the eighth annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships will be staged at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island this afternoon. There will be fifteen varsity events and a similar number of freshman tests, with the field competition beginning at 12:30 and the track at 2:30.

Mary's Day will be observed today on the eve of Mother's Day with a special mass at 9 A.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral under the auspices of the International Mary's Day Committee, It will be the first such service in the cathedral.

With one more day of play re maining the Women's National and Piping Rock teams are running a nip-and-tuck race for Class A honors in the interclub golf series now being played by the Long Island women.

LONDON, May 10--In the gravest crisis Great Britain has faced since the World War, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister tonight as Allied armies raced across Belgium again for a death grapple with invading German armies.

Colonel Bill Terry's Giants yesterday demonstrated to the gayly arrogant league leaders, the Dodgers, the truth of the homely adage that "everything that goes up must come down."

The Allied Relief Ball was held at the Hotel Astor last night for the benefit of French and British non-combatant war relief. Occurring on the eve of the opening of the World's Fair, the hall was the largest of the Spring season, with informal gayety reminiscent of the old Beaux-Arts parties.

WASHINGTON, May 10--The Administration quickly closed the door today against withdrawal of an estimated $1,100,000,000 of liquid Belgian and Netherland investments in this country by extending the embargo recently declared against movements of Danish and Norwegian credits to cover the property of Belgium and the Nethlends and their nationals.

The best meeting the Metropolitan Jockey Club has had in its long history comes to a close at Jamaica today with the running of the $7,500 added Excelsior Handicap and the $2,500 added Youthful Stakes as the twin features.

The volume of new bond offerings this week dwindled to the smallest figure in about three months, amounting to only $5,718,968, as compared with $91,546,000 last week. During this period a year ago $12,907,800 in new bonds were placed on the market.
Yesterday morning Eddie Cantor signed a radio contract containing a clause which for the first time in the history of radio provides for a sliding weekly compensation on the basis of a CAB rating.

Representatives of the Atlas Corporation and the Curtiss-Wright Corporation met yesterday afternoon to consider the feasibility of consummating the merger plan announced by them on March 19 and decided that the opposition which had grown up against the proposal had ended any chance of its success.

The death of an elevator operator,c a white-haired man, who had been a familiar figure to doctors, nurses, patients and reporters in Bellevue Hospital for nine years, revealed yesterday the story of a man who had given up the medical profession after a long and successful practice, because his mother's death had shattered his interest in life and in his profession.

Defeating the Salle Santelli representatives in the deciding test, the New York A.C. team retained the national saber championship last night at the Winged Foot clubhouse.

Dr. J. Herman Wylie, a medical missionary for the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America on the staff of the Douw Hospital, Peiping, China, died on Tuesday in Bloomington, Ill., according to word received by the board here yesterday. The German invasion of the Low Countries automatically closed all Netherland and Belgian markets, although several banks here reported yesterday that they had been in communication with banks in Amsterdam.

PARIS. Saturday, May 11--The first German air attacks on French objectives were carried out in many parts of the country yesterday, but although they were minutely planned, according to a report this evening by an official army spokesman, they were not successful. Moreover, this same report declares, civilian populations were deliberately bombed by the raiders.

The Actors Fund of America finished its fifty-eighth year with a deficit of $11,257, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting in the National Theatre, in West Forty-first Street.

He has staked everything on a gigantic gamble which, if he wins, will mean the end of freedom and democracy and culture throughout all Europe in our time.

Peace and good-will are proclaimed today on Flushing Meadows. The Halls of Nations stand, in memory and hope of work well and truly done and to be done. The inventive mind, the creative hand, the honest buyers and sellers of goods, are not damned and scorned here --this is their day of honor. Poland, Norway, Denmark, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, little Luxembourg, live here in freedom. No leering murderers ride the air overhead.

The United States District Court in Pittsburgh approved yesterday reorganization of the Follansbee Brothers Company, directed consummation of the plan of reorganization that was approved on Jan. 6 and specified procedure. Judge Robert M. Gibson signed the order.

CHICAGO; May 10--Roger W. Babson, economist, of Massachusetts was nominated for President today by the Prohibition party at the closing session of its three day national convention here.

The vanguard of out-of-town visitors to the World's Fair arrived yesterday, and James A. MaCarthy, secretary of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., reiterated that the 183 hotels in the association with their 77,000 rooms had accommodations at reasonable rates for every person.

Supplies steer hinds and ribs moderate to normal; veal about normal; lamb uneven, normal in some sections, light in others; pork normal; cow and bull moderate. Demand for hinds and ribs was mostly slow, veal and lamb fair to good, and pork fair in local markets yesterday.

Continuing its economy program, the Board of Education is planning to drop three high school annexes and two elementary schools in Brooklyn at the end of this semester, it was announced yesterday. Formal action on the discontinuance of the schools will be taken at the board's annual meeting Tuesday afternoon.

BOSTON, May 10--Changes in the Securities Act to cure the "serious vices" of private sale of choicest securities, and State control instead of government "super regulation" of utilities, were advocated at the Hotel Statler today as the climax of the convention of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the three months ended on March 31, issued yesterday by Roy B. White, president, showed a net income of $210,472, after all expenses and charges.

AKRON, Ohio, May 13--The world champion Yankees, on their way to St. Louis where they will open their first invasion of the West against the Browns tomorrow, stopped off here today for an exhibition game with their Akron...

Supplies steer hinds and ribs barely normal; veal normal; lamb uneven, light to normal; other classes moderate. Demand for hinds and ribs only fair to slow; lamb, veal and pork mostly fair; cow and bull only fair, in local markets yesterday. Pork loins were mostly $1 higher; other classes and cuts mostly unchanged. The kosher market opened steady to mostly 50c lower ...
Peter A. Carey, who served as Brooklyn's Borough President for two weeks in 1933, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, after a short illness. He was 67 years old.
BASLE, Switzerland, May 13 (AP)-- French artillery and Allied air bombs this afternoon shattered part of the Istein railroad tunnel under Germany's "Gibraltar of the Rhine."

Mail orders for sports wear and Summer dresses increased here yesterday, the volume showing a gain over last Monday. Milder weather last week spurted consumer demand for Summer goods, but reports indicated buying has yet to reach large proportions. Some merchandisers expressed the belief that the total war abroad may mean a period of conservative consumer purchasing, to be followed later by active buying.

A series of conferences and educational activities, emphasizing closer relationship and cooperation of the American republics in culture, travel and trade, are being planned for the Inter-America House, which occupies the Former Argentine Pavilion at the Fair. The definite plans and date of the formal opening of the building will be announced soon.

CHICAGO, May 13--Delegates to the convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, which will open a four-day meeting here tomorrow, are reported to have brought resolutions favoring a third term for President Roosevelt.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 13--The board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America formally approved today a program of educational and public-relations activities believed to be the most ambitious ever undertaken by any group in the underwriting industry.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., May 13-- School ended for the members of the New Jersey section of the P. G.A. today and the graduates celebrated by putting the knowledge they had gained during the initial educational golf clinic into practice.

Today the Hon. Samuel Houston Jones will be inducted Governor of Louisiana. Instead of a splendiferous inauguration ball such as Huey Long and his immediate successors delighted in, he will treat all comers to a barbecue in the football stadium of the State University.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 13--The Women's National Class A team of five, consisting of Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., Mrs. F.K. Thayer Jr., Mrs V.D. Crisp, Mrs. Joseph C. Dey Jr. and Mrs. J.B. Balding, won the Long Island division title...
A solution to the thefts of $3,000 in WPA pay checks was reported yesterday by Federal investigators, who brought about the arrest of a minor WPA executive and a former timekeeper.

LONDON, May 13--The thunder of the great battle now started in the Low Countries will not prevent the British from keeping a close watch on Premier Mussolini. The situation in Rome is swiftly coming down to the sharp point when Italy will come out into the open in support of her German ally. That is the view of experts in London.
LONDON, May 13--Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands has arrived in London, a refugee. She came from the Netherlands to England aboard a British warship.
Pessimism over the latest war bulletins on the campaign in the Low Countries tumbled prices in the securities market yesterday and weakened grains and several of the lesser commodities.

While Samuel Reshevsky, national titleholder, and Isaac I. Kashdan still the leader among seventeen contenders, played for four hours without reaching a decision in the thirteenth round of the United States Chess Federation championship tournament at the Hotel Aston last night, Abraham Kupchik of the Manhattan Chess Club emerged as the sole victor in that session.

WASHINGTON, May 13--An agreement was reached today by the Senate to vote tomorrow on Senator McCarran's resolution to invalidate President Roosevelt's Reorganization Plan No. 4, involving transfer of the Civil Aeronautics Authority to the Department of Commerce and abolition of the Air Safety Board.

Colonel Gustave Porjes, who helped supervise the purchase of all food supplies for the United States Expeditionary Forces in France during the World War, died on Sunday at the Mount Sinai Hospital. He was in his sixties and resided at the Hotel Plaza.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)--The War Department estimated today that 310,000 officers and men of the regular Army, National Guard and Reserve Corps would be under arms during the August manoeuvres.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 13-- George Oberteuffer, National Academician and nationally known painter and instructor in art, died today of pneumonia at the Addison Gilbert Hospital. He was 62 years old.

The statement of Major Gen. H.H. Arnold, Chief of the Army Air Corps, that our own service is not yet convinced of the value of parachute troops in modern war is somewhat surprising in view of what is happening in the Low Countries. Such troops are plainly being used by Germany to great advantage.

BOSTON, May 13--Colonel Bill Terry's astonishing Giant steamroller, which seems to be gaining momentum with each day, pulverized Professor Casey Stengel's Bees, 11 to 5, today. This gave the New Yorkers a clean sweep of the threegame series and extended their streak to six victories in a row.
BERLIN, May 13--The German Government today formally warned the governments of Britain, Belgium, France and the Netherlands ...

WASHINGTON, May 13--Public sentiment for the Allied cause menaced by the Nazi drive was reflected in Congress today by renewed discussion of the possibility of loans to the Allies, which would involve revocation or modification of the Johnson and Neutrality Acts.

The Jamaica Savings Bank filed plans yesterday for a six-story apartment house to cost $150,000, at 90-15 161st Street, Jamaica. Other projects submitted in the city included a number of small dwellings, business buildings in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, as well as alterations to existing buildings in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Secretary Hull today denounced nations which have reduced science "to the sorry estate of a handmaiden of oppression and brute force" and called upon the scientists of the Western Hemisphere to persevere in their "loyalty to the human race and the destiny of man."

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of James G. McDonald as a member of the Board of Education to fill the unexpired term of Henry C. Turner, after receiving the resignation Mr. Turner had contemplated for the last two years.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13-- Princeton handed Cornell its first Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat by a 9-3 score in the opening game of a double-header on University Field today, but the Ithacans came back to win the nightcap, 6--4, behind the four-hit pitching of Kyle Morse.
On Friday evening last I received from His Majesty the mission to form a new administration.

Mrs. Ole Hagen, wife of the United States Naval Attache in Scandinavia, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan, via Italy, carrying a diplomatic mail pouch that contained the ashes of Captain Robert M. Losey, air attache in Norway, who was killed while observing a Nazi air raid.

The report for 1939 of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, released for publication today, shows, after all charges, taxes and reserves, a consolidated net income of $89,128,756, equal to $3.28 each on the 27,285,919 shares of capital stock and scrip outstanding at the...

WASHINGTON, May 13--The lot of the American farm laborer is harder, his burden of responsibility is heavier and his standard of living is the lowest of any occupational group in this country, C. Horace Hamilton of the Agricultural Department's Division of Farm Population and Rural Welfare told the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman officiated yesterday in groundbreaking ceremonies for the new $2,500,000 Cardinal Hayes Memorial High School for boys in the Bronx, the first large Catholic high school to be erected in the archdiocese in recent years.

WASHINGTON, May 13--President Roosevelt will send a message to Congress this week, probably on Thursday, asking a substantial increase in appropriations for the national defense. Army and navy officials are making a survey of their pressing needs. Secretaries Morgenthau and Woodring, Assistant Secretary Johnson and General George C. Marshall conferred with the President today.

World's Fairs, we find, are things you get used to. You wander on the Meadow and it seems as though the music in the air, Sidewalks-of-New York horns and guide book salesmen are things you have known since childhood. The days on the Meadow are short and pleasant. You move through them as in a dream, with thousands of other lotus and hot-dog eaters.
