EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 13 --The Fresh Meadow team of Henry Ciuci and Philip Leff broke par by four strokes to win the weekly pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 68 at Wheatley Hills today.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Without a roll-call vote the House passed and sent to the Senate today the Rankin bill to pension all dependent widows, children and parents of World War veterans, regardless of whether their deaths were caused by service disabilities.

WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Belgium, May 13--A battle such as the world has never seen before is now beginning just inside Belgium's eastern border, where invading Germans have smashed in the first serious barrier of this country. The battle is not going too well from the standpoint of the Allies, and the situation today can only be described as grave, though it is not hopeless.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y., announced yesterday that it will be in the market on May 21 with a new issue of $2,500,000 of bonds. The obligations will be dated June 1, 1940, and will mature serially from June 1, 1941 to 1950.

HONG KONG, Tuesday, May 14 (AP)--Reported collapse of Japanese lines in Central China in the Honan and Hupeh border areas was hailed by Chinese dispatches today as a major Japanese setback, one of the worst of the war.

Testimony establishing a corpus delicti and setting the stage for submission of proof of murder was given yesterday at the first trial arising from District Attorney William O'Dwyer's investigation into the Brooklyn murder syndicate.

Plans for the formation of two nation-wide organizations, composed respectively of American and Belgian women, to aid in the relief of the civilian population of Belgium were announced here yesterday.

Current magazine phenomenon is Mademoiselle, the May issue of which led all monthly magazines with 159 pages of advertising, almost triple the May, 1939, total of fifty-four pages. Latest circulation figures are 340,000, as against 178,000 a year ago, 97,000 for May, 1938, and 16,000 for May, 1935.

TOKYO, May 13 (AP)--Great Britain and the Netherlands both assured Japan today they had no intention of altering the status quo in the Netherlands' rich East Indies possessions.

The late Ferdinand Hodler is making, through his pictures, an appearance in Fifty-seventh Street. Although the Swiss artist died in 1918, he has come to seem more remote than that. Actually, Hodler was painting in very much the "modern" manner at the end of his life. And yet, born in 1853, he was identified, through more than half of his career, with nineteenth century European art currents.

Captain John T. Prout Jr. testified yesterday in the Federal Court in Brooklyn that while he was in command of a machine-gun company of the 165th Infantry, New York National Guard, last Fall he gave William Gerald Bishop about 1,500 rounds of .30-caliber ammunition and about a dozen cans of cordite that he knew to be government property.
CINCINNATI, May 13--Starting late because no umpires had been assigned to the game, the Reds and Cards battled to a fourteen-inning, 8-to-8 tie today. Darkness stopped the contest.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., May 13-- An assertion that American youth must renew its devotion to democracy was made today by President Herman G. James of Ohio University in addressing a conference at Indiana University designed to map cooperation between universities and civic groups on a plan for better self-government.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Secretary of State Cordell Hull was cautious in discussing at his press conference today the suggestion of the Argentine Government for revision of the neutrality policies of the twenty-one American republics to convert them to a status of nonbelligerency.

With high praise for the manner in which the French have responded to the task of caring for both the evacues from their own war zones and the large numbers of Spanish refugees within their care, Howard E. Kershner, director of relief in France and Spain of the American Friends Committee, returned here yesterday from Paris on the liner Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 13--If the President were known to have determined not to accept a third nomination, the Senate tomorrow would undoubtedly follow the action of the House in rejecting Reorganisation Order No. 4, which ends the independent status of the Civil Aeronautics Authority and makes it a bureau of the Department of Commerce.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 13 (AP)--Harvard players paced representatives from ten colleges as play opened today in the forty-first annual New England intercollegiate tennis tournament. The Crimson has John Palfrey and Langdon...

PARIS, May 13--The fury of such aerial warfare as already has martyrized Finland, Poland and Norway has now swept over the Netherlands, Belgium and France. German bombers have attacked roads and railway lines choked with defenseless caravans of refugees from Liege, Namur and Belgian Ardennes.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Demands for heavy increases in army and air corps personnel and equipment were voiced today in a Senate debate.

PARIS, May 13--Refugees of all ages from the invaded provinces of Belgium and Luxembourg streamed through the Paris stations in increasing numbers today. All had tales of misery and privation, many of them told of having been machine-gunned or bombed during their flight.

In spite of the elaborate preparations, the opening of Belmont Park yesterday failed by a considerable margin to come up to expectations. Facilities were adequate at the beautiful plant, but the attendance and the pari-mutuel handle did not approach the hopes of those who had been saying: "Wait until we get to Belmont."

So-called nerve paralyzing gas, such as speculation has indicated might be the "new weapon" claimed by Berlin to have been used by the German forces in Belgium, is not new to warfare. Such a gas might be a German adaptation or derivative of some deadly gas discovered by chemists during the World War.

WASHINGTON, May 13--The world is threatened with "an orgy of destruction not only of life and property but of religion, of morality, of the very bases of civilized society," Secretary Hull declared tonight.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 13-- Thousands of persons, including representatives of many mercantile establishments in the metropolitan area, inspected the new branch of Franklin Simon's at 544 Central Avenue here after it was opened today.

THIS morning Jonathan Daniels makes another remarkable first-hand report on the state of certain States in the Union. Several years ago he traveled through the cotton and Coca-Cola belt, of which he, as a Raleigh, N.C., editor (and as Josephus Daniels's son) , is a native. Last year he traveled through Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island and Connecticut.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13-- Increased study about the Central and South American countries in the grade and high schools is the object of the campaign to be waged by the Educational Policies Commission.

Charles B. Harding, of Smith, Barney Co. was elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange to succeed Edward E. Bartlett Jr. of Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt. He will serve a one-year term, beginning on Monday.

The bright colors of new styles for women's clothing and hats gave a festive air yesterday at the opening of the racing season at Belmont Park. Almost every color and every shade was present in a variety of styles that ranged from the simplicity of tweeds to the formal dignity of furs.

Fifty persons attended a funeral service yesterday in the Bellevue Mortuary Chapel for Dr. Lewis Nathaniel Foote, 68-year-old physician, who for the last nine years worked as a Bellevue Hospital elevator operator without disclosing his profession to his associates. The doctor died a week ago yesterday, but was not publicly identified until Friday.
ROME, May 13--There were demonstrations all over Italy this morning under the Fascist party's direction to arouse patriotic sentiments for war and hatred for Great Britain.
Sir George and Lady Bettesworth-Piggott, who passed the Winter and early Spring in Florida, are at the Plaza, to stay for a few weeks.

ALBANY, May 13--Governor Lehman today named members of the State Harness Horse Racing Commission provided for in the parimutuel betting law. The members are Jacob C. Newton of Hamburg, Elbridge T. Gerry of New York and Benjamin W. Downing of Manhasset, L.I.

Production on nylon hosiery was thrown open to any manufacturer who can buy yarn, and all restrictions upon prices and labeling were waived in a sweeping action yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. which, while officially unexplained, was traced by observers to a desire to avoid anti-trust prosecution in view of recent decisions of the Supreme Court in the Ethyl gasoline and Madison oil cases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13-- Fred MacMurray will play the lead in Warners' "Honeymoon Three" opposite Olivia De Havilland, the studio announced today. MacMurray will replace James Stewart, who has switched from "Honeymoon" to "No Time for Comedy." The MacMurray assignment fulfills a long-standing commitment Warners has had to borrow the actor from Paramount.

Steel operations this week are scheduled to surge forward to 70 per cent of capacity in the second successive week of gain, for the broadest advance to be registered since the middle of September, 1939, soon after the beginning of war in Europe.

PARIS, May 13--With the utmost violence of which they are capable and making full use of armored columns and airplanes, the German armies today began a mass attack from Arnhem in the Netherlands to the Moselle River, a front of approximately 200 miles. At all points fighting has been exceedingly fierce.

If studies cited by Dr. W.E. Cole of the University of Tennessee are typical, women are a little more likely than men to be happy in a state of matrimony. Dr. Cole is properly cautious about taking fragmentary evidence as final, but the data on hand suggest that one out of three husbands and two out of seven wives are discontented.

A number of manufacturers of pharmaceuticals sought yesterday to increase their inventories of quinine salts to the equivalent of three years' normal needs, but importers refused to sell any unduly large quantities. In many instances supplies were allotted and orders for 5,000 ounces frequently were cut to as little as 1,000 ounces.

The storm that has broken over Western Europe gathers intensity with every hour. Correspondents behind the lines describe it as a hurricane. Swarms of German war planes have preceded the hurrying tanks and troops, smashing communications, terrorizing civil populations, dropping soldiers from the skies to add to the confusion and horror.
BERLIN, May 13--The Germans tonight were well on their way into the heart of Belgium; they claimed to have successfully turned the Liege defenses and to have captured the city itself.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 13--The Princeton Theological Seminary will hold its 128th graduation ceremonies tomorrow morning in the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of the institution, will confer degrees on a class of seventy-four.

There are those who do not consider this tendency justified, in view of the fact that it is not considered wise for the government to reveal all it is doing.

CAMP BEAUREGARD, La., May 13--Representative Snyder of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Expenditures, outlined here today an armament program to make the United States "prepared for any eventuality."

The music of Ernest Schelling, American musician, who died last December, spoke eloquently for him at a concert in his memory at Carnegie Hall last night. Especially in the final work of the program, "A Victory Ball," the late composer seemed to be as contemporary and apposite as today's headline.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14-- Twentieth Century-Fox signed John Barrymore today to play himself in "The Great Profile," a story by Melville Crossman based on Barrymore's appearance in "My Dear Children," which will close its Broadway run Saturday.

CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP)--Al Simmons's ninth-inning pinch single with the bases full gave Philadelphia two runs and a 9-to-7 victory in its series opener with the Cleveland Indians today, the Athletics shelling Bob Feller from the mound and pounding two other hurlers for a total of fifteen hits.

After ten weeks of evidence, the eleventh week of the McKesson Robbins fraud trial opened in Federal Court yesterday with counsel summing up for two banker-directors and the controller of the huge drug concern charged with complicity in a decade of inflation under F. Donald Coster.

Bishop Manning, delivering his annual charge to the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday, brought 600 clerical and lay members to their feet to applaud him when he declared it the "duty" of the United States to give "immediately our utmost material assistance" to the Allies.
WASHINGTON, May 14--Brig. Gen. Everard E. Hatch, United States Army, retired, veteran of two wars died in Walter Reed General Hospital this morning at the age of 80.

LONDON, May 14--Aroused by the effectiveness of German parachute troops in the invasion of the Netherlands, the British War Office announced tonight that a big home front army of non-paid volunteers will be formed immediately to forestall any Nazi attempt to invade Great Britain by air.
BERLIN, May 14--Former Kaiser Wilhelm II is again under the protection of the German Army but not the army he left defeated when he bolted into the Netherlands two days before the Armistice in 1918.
A large number of renewals and many new leases calling for store space featured the contracts for commercial quarters reported by brokers yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,825,450 barrels, an increase of 146,400 over the 3,679,050 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14--The Women's League of the United Synagogue of America, closing its annual convention in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here today, urged that all possible steps be taken to keep America out of war.

Great Britain and France have placed large orders for steel in this country during the last few days to replace the apparent loss of the normal supply from Belgium and Luxembourg as well as the stoppage of iron ore imports from Sweden and Norway over the last month, it was learned yesterday.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 14--The price that the Labor party is asking for agreeing to enter the British Government and swinging the full Laborite trade union resources into the war is a Socialist system after the war.

Louis Lustig, vice president of the Capital Insuring Company at 215 West Thirty-seventh Street, and long prominent in the cloak and suit industry, died yesterday at his residence, 250 West Ninety-fourth Street, after an illness of two months. He was in his sixty-sixth year.

Dr. Theodosius Dobzhansky, Professor of Genetics in the California Institute of Technology, and Dr. Marcus M. Rhoades, geneticist of the United States Department of Agriculture, have been named to the faculty of Columbia University to direct research in the university's laboratory of genetics, founded two years ago to merge botanical and zoological efforts in attacking the mysteries of growth and inheritance.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The House Judiciary Committee today adopted five amendments to the Hatch "Clean State Politics" Bill and decided to consider the bill further on Thursday. In the absence of Representative Sumners, chairman, who is ill, the committee rejected by 15 to 8 another motion to table the measure.

PURCHASE, N. Y., May 14--The Joseph J. Windle Challenge Cup was won by Mrs. DeWitt Untermeyer of Hollywood today after she tied with Miss Margaret Mackie of Inwood and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches at 2 down to par on the Century Club golf course.
WESTFIELD, N. J., May 14--Jacob L. Bauer, former State highway engineer and former Union County engineer, died this morning at his home here after a long illness.

The plant property at 407-21 New Jersey Railroad Avenue, between Murray and Astor Streets, Newark, N. J., has been purchased by Baker Co., Inc., from the Mountain Ice Company.

In an effort to stimulate smallhome construction in Westchester County, a group of bankers, realty men and county officials has proposed that building mechanics there accept a voluntary reduction in wage rates.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The American Red Cross speeded up its program for aid to the war-sticken countries of Western Europe, today ordering Wayne Chatfield Taylor, head of its European mission, to proceed to Brussels to map a plan of relief for Belgium.

LONDON, May 14--Many priceless masterpieces of Netherland art have been stored in secret hiding places in the Netherlands, where they are presumably intact, according to G. Bolkestein, Netherland Minister of Education, Art, Science and Education.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The War Department has asked President Roosevelt to approve an immediate increase of 15,000 men in the size of the regular army, officials said today. This number could be recruited with reasonable speed.
LONDON, May 14--German attacks on various European countries have resulted in substantial increases in Allied merchant shipping tonnage.

BERLIN, May 14--National socialism is no longer only for domestic consumption but is an export article, for export not only to the rest of Europe but to the world, according to Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front and one of the leading party philosophers.

AMSTERDAM, May 14--All but a small part of the Netherlands capitulated to the invading German Army tonight "to prevent further bloodshed and annihilation" when General Henri Gerard Winkelman, the Commander in Chief, called upon his troops to lay down their arms.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The House today sent back to conference the Agricultural and Labor Department-Federal Security Agency Appropriation Bills after accepting some Senate and compromise provisions but rejecting or modifying others.

Thomas F. Curley, Clerk of the County of Richmond for the last sixteen months, former member of the Legislature and former assistant corporation counsel of this city, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 100 Castleton Park, St. George, S. I. His age was 56.

A hold-up with a sawed-off shotgun was staged at the box-office of the Belasco Theatre, 115 West Forty-fourth Street, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, where John Barrymore is starring in "My Dear Children," and led to a police chase just after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon with the capture of a young man charged with the robbery.

Eleven municipalities in New Jersey held city commission, elections yesterday. The most spirited contest in the State was waged at Montclair, where a Citizens ticket, headed by Mayor William E. Speers, won the election over forces led by James J. McMahon, Montclair, and Essex County Democratic chairman and a first lieutenant of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

An informal fashion breakfast was held yesterday morning by Saks Fifth Avenue on the fifth floor of the store. The guests, all experts in the field of style, were invited to view a collection of Summer clothes. The display was in two sections, one dealing with sophisticated town-and-country and the other with sports styles.
YONKERS, N. Y., May 14--Dr. Hannah Yoseph Jacobs, a retired physician, died on Sunday night at her home here, 272 South Broadway, after a two-month illness. Her age was 71.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd returned here yesterday from Antarctica with his first personal report of the work of the United States Antarctic Service Expedition. Hammering three Violet pitchers for fourteen hits, including six that were good for extra bases, the St. John's baseball team gained its seoond victory of the season over New York University yesterday, triumphing to the tune of 11 to 6 at Ohio Field.

TRENTON, May 22--Complete unofficial returns from New Jersey's 3,631 voting districts in yesterday's primary elections give State Senafor Robert C. Hendrickaon the Republican nomination for Governor by a margin of 34,396 over former Governor Harold G. Hoffman.
BERLIN, May 22--A German newsreel, shown to correspondents today, revealed the appalling aspects of the destruction of Rotterdam.

LONDON, May 22--The British Parliament passed in 150 minutes today an unprecedented bill that gives the government the right to conscript every person, every piece of property and every penny in the realm--a bill that virtually suspends for the duration of the war the ancient liberties of this democratic kingdom.

A syndicate of investors headed by Lech Yejeski leased the southeast corner of Broadway and Fulton Street for sixty-three years from the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church and will replace the old ten-story Evening Post Building on the site with a modern business structure.

LONDON, May 22--The slow but sure grinding down of German economy under the British blockade spurted Chancellor Hitler to make his desperate thrust in the realization that the German people could not face another Winter, authoritative circles in London said today.

George J. Robinson of 8220 Colonial Road, Brooklyn, former president of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, and a director of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, died Tuesday night in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

Mrs. Frederic R. Coudert gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz Tower. Among her guests were Mrs. Godfrey Haggard, wife of the British Consul General at New York; Mrs. Casimir de Rham, Mrs. Charles H. Sherrill, Mrs. H. Edward Manville, Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, Mrs. Orme Wilson, Mrs. James W. Gerard, Mrs. Robert E. Tod, Mrs. Nelson B. Burr and Mrs. Ansel Phelps.

Poly Prop's baseball team triumphed on its home field over St. Michael's High of Brooklyn by 7 to 5 yesterday for its sixth straight victory and ita sixth in eight games this season. Frank Castelli, St. Michael's catcher, made three hits, including a homer and a triple, in four turns at bat.
CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP)--The Indians beat the league-leading Red Sox today at their own game--slugging--and blasted a 9-to-6 victory which lifted the Tribe within a game and a half of first place.

TOKYO, May 22--In an answer giving Japan more than she had asked for, the German Ambassador, Major Gen. Eugen Ott, informed Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita today that the German Government was "not interested in the Netherlands Indies problem."

A large dinner dance entitled "Fete Parisienne" was given last night at the Hotel Brevoort to raise funds for the Benedict Bureau Unit, a volunteer organization in Paris serving a French military hospital.
Baptized or confirmed members of the Lutheran Church, "who feel unwilling for conscience' sake to take human life in war," may re
WITH THE GERMAN ARMY OF OCCUPATION, Rotterdam, May 22--This beautiful Netherland city, principal shipping center for a far-flung Colonial empire, is today a sad skeleton of its former self.

Ten sergeants were added to the army recruiting forces here and further additions are contemplated by the army to handle the rush of enlistments, it was announced yesterday at the local army recruiting office, which is conducting the greatest peacetime enlistment drive in the history of the Second Corps Area.
WASHINGTON, May 22--President Roosevelt today nominated Sumner T. Pike, a business man and Republican to succeed George C. Mathews as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Certificates attesting to their proficiency as domestic help were awarded yesterday to sixteen refugees, marking the successful completion of a seven-week experimental class in retraining men and women exiles for a new life in this country.

School Superintendent Campbell and his assistants had difficulty in selecting from many nominations the twenty-five teachers in the city school system whom he cited this week for their "unselfish devotion" to their jobs and to the children under their care.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, commanding general of the Twentyseventh Division in Belgium and France during the last war, urged yesterday that Congress immediately authorize the detachment from the regular military services of aircraft carriers, transports, protecting naval vessels and at least 2,000

LONDON, May 22--In a fresh war effort, all branches of industry and labor pledged themselves today to redouble their exertions and cooperate with the government in its intensified drive to speed production of armaments and vital commodities.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The liner President Roosevelt will sail from New York, probably tomorrow night, for Ireland to bring back Americans stranded in the European war zone, the State Department announced tonight. Belligerents were warned not to molest her.
Large apartment properties and taxpayers figured largely in the Bronx realty trading yesterday, when investors took over several parcels.

WHILE New Jersey is still the unknown land of Nova Caesarea to most Americans, especially those on the near bank of the Hudson or the far bank of the Delaware, of late there have been portents, and it may be that a great awakening is due.

The precarious Allied situation on the Western Front was not decisively changed yesterday, although the French claimed the recapture of Arras and hard-fighting poilus commenced to consolidate their lines along the Somme and the Aisne Rivers.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Bombing planes are flying under their own power from American factories to the battle fields of Europe, Arthur B. Purvis, head of the Anglo-French purchasing mission, asserted today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 22--Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National and Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow each posted an 84 and tied for low-gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association on the hilly and difficult North Shore Country Club course today.

John H. McGloon, who was controller and vice president of McKesson Robbins during the decade while the ex-convict, Philip Musica, alias F. Donald Coster, was inflating its assets by $21,000,000, was sentenced for complicity yesterday in Federal district court to one year and a day and fined $5,000.

Cooperation by the States in obtaining uniform food and drug legislation is lacking, and in many instances the States are including in such laws provisions which create trade barriers, Dr. Frederick J. Cullen, executive vice president of the Proprietary Association of...

OTTAWA, May 22 (Canadian Press)--The Most Rev. Joseph Guillaume Forbes, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Ottawa since 1928, died here today after a long illness at the age of 74. He had served fifty-two years in the church.
ALBANY, May 22 (AP)--Three new directors were elected today at the annual meeting of New York Central Railroad stockholders.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Alfred M. Landon, titular head of the Republican party, demanded today that President Roosevelt disavow the move to give him "a third or indefinite term" as the Republican price for an interparty alliance for the executive conduct of the national defense program.

BERLIN, May 22 (AP)--The German High Command accused British and French troops today of using Belgian civilians as shields and charged that other violations of international law were practiced by the Allies.
An emergency shipment of 1,810 pounds of surgical dressings, prepared by volunteers of the American Red Cross, was rushed under motor cycle police escort yesterday to La Guardia Field.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, representing 16,000 city policemen, has decided to ask the City Council to authorize the elevensquad system instead of the present ten-squad system.

President Roosevelt's plan for 50,000 American war planes would involve the training of three pilots for each plane in order to develop their full effectiveness, it was said yesterday by Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, World War ace and president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines.

WASHINGTON, May 22--In a reply tonight to Colonel Lindbergh's broadcast speech of Sunday night, Senator Byrnes likened his address and its assertion that the United States should avoid hysteria regarding the war situation, to "fifth column activities" among the Allied countries of Europe.
PARIS, May 22--"If every one will do his duty with driving energy," France can still be saved.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from the administrator of the division of public contracts in the Department of Labor, taking exception to certain factual statements made in an editorial in THE TIMES of May 1 regarding the manner in which minimum wages have been determined by the department under the Walsh-Healey act.
A rebound in the free-market rate for the pound sterling carried that currency up to $3.24 yesterday. The law of the day was $3.21. The final price of $3.23 showed a net gain of 5 cents on the day.
DETROIT, May 22--Walloping four of Del Baker's hurlers for sixteen hits, the Yankees tamed the Tigers by 8 to 2 today and sneaked once again out of the cellar.

The impossibility of isolating the world of tomorrow, as exemplified by the World's Fair, from the grimmest aspect of the world of today was further emphasized yesterday in a joint announcement by the Commissioners General of the Allied nations.

LONDON, May 22--Red-eyed from lack of sleep and tense from hour after hour of flying and fighting, British pilots today pressed home their attacks on German mechanized columns in the teeth of superior air forces.
CAMP BEAUREGARD, La., May 22--The entire plan of the final phase of the Third Army manoeuvres was changed today to provide the 70,000 men with training in the German type of attack.

Nothing Germany has done in the last two weeks in her aerial warfare over France, Belgium and the Netherlands was new to the Allied commands, Howard Welch, executive vice president of the Bendix Aviation Company, producers of instruments for aircraft, said here yesterday.
Operating, as it is, on a day-today news basis, the stock market managed yesterday to throw off some of the heavy gloom on reports of Allied successes against the German columns.

A proposal to reduce the assessment rate for Federal deposit insurance from the present one-twelfth of 1 per cent, or $833 for each $1,000,000 of deposits, to one-sixteenth of 1 per cent, or $625 a $1,000,000, was advanced yesterday by Guy Emerson, vice president of

LONDON, May 22--Alfred Duff Cooper, the Minister of Information, declared in a radio address to the empire today that in the total war into which the Germans had plunged the world, every citizen was in the line of battle and that "the hour has already sounded for the utmost effort from us all."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 22--Infuriated by a grievance, Matthew Gillespie, 62-year-old janitor at the junior school of the Dwight School for Girls here, shot and critically wounded Mrs. Marshall Coxe, secretary of the junior school, on the first floor of the building this afternoon.

Dr. Christian Gauss, dean of the School of Fine Arts and Sciences, Princeton University, who signed a petition of the American Association of Scientific Workers urging that the United States remain at peace, announced yesterday that he had changed his mind. To remain neutral at present, he explained, "seems to me a short-sighted shirking of moral responsibility."

The machine tool industry is short of neither men nor capacity for meeting the sharp expansion in its operations that has resulted from the war, and export orders, although large, are being held down to a small enough percentage of total volume to assure an adequate supply of machine-tool capacity for domestic needs, Raymond S. Perry, vice president of the Ingersoll Milling Machine Company, Rockford, Ill., said here yesterday.
Mayor, La Guardia signed two way for construction of the Battery-Brooklyn tunnel. Announcing his action at the World's Fair City Hall the Mayor said:

World economic conditions make cooperation among advertisers, agencies and media vital at this time, George McMillan, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, pointed out yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export

WASHINGTON, May 22--When the President looked across his desk today at Alfred M. Landon, he was, of course, looking at his Republican opponent of 1936, who got 17 million votes to Mr. Roosevelt's 28 million.

A merger involving two important real estate firms in this city has been consummated, it was revealed yesterday when Peter Grimm, president of Wm. A. White Sons, and Leonard S. Gang jointly announced that the Leonard S. Gans Company will be consolidated with the White organization June 15.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 22-- Three officials of the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I. O.) were arrested late this afternoon in front of the gates of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant as they attempted to pass out union handbills in defiance of a Dearborn ordinance.

MOSCOW, May 22--A communique issued here tonight on the subject of the recent Anglo-Soviet exchange of views on the possibility of opening negotiations for a commercial treaty confirms the impression reached when the question first was raised that at present no such possibility exists.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture said today that it would make loans to growers on surplus 1940-grown rye at a maximum rate of 38 cents a bushel.

Allied plans for financing the European conflict in part through increased export sales will have to be sacrificed to the need for marshaling all productive facilities in supplying munitions and war supplies, as a result of the intensified warfare which has developed in Northern France, foreign traders said here yesterday.

Dr. Theodore Meyer Greene, Professor of Philosophy at Princeton University, counseled the graduates of the General Theological Seminary yesterday at commencement against "an other-worldly indifference to man's present individual and social needs and duties."

WASHINGTON, May 22--The House, in Committee of the Whole, tentatively approved today the $975,000,000 WPA fund requested by President Roosevelt in the pending Relief Bill, together with the authority to spend it in eight months, but failed to bring the bill to final passage, as expected, in the face of a barrage of amendments to this and other items in the measure.

The building of a great merchant marine, not only to increase foreign trade but also to forge a "strong right arm" for the navy, was urged last night by Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward and C.H.C. Pearsall, executive vice president of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Line.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 (AP)--Yugoslavia and Greece, it was disclosed tonight, have removed their war planes from military airports lest their air force be destroyed in a sudden outbreak of war as the Polish air fleet was last September.

OTTAWA, May 22--The Canadian Parliament went into high gear today, putting through the bill establishing a Ministry of Defense for Air in record time. The bill passed Commons and Senate, received the Royal assent and became law in less than three hours.
As the season of outdoor dog shows gets into full swing, dog lovers have an opportunity to enjoy the obedience tests which continue to gain in popularity at bench shows.

ROME, May 22--Tension deliberately fostered by the government continued here today, but it was accompanied in some quarters by the hope that Germany's smashing victory in France would permit Italy to get all she wanted without going to war.

PITTSBURGH, May 22--A plea for America to be on the alert against activities of "fifth column" workers and the expressed opinion that "present-day anti-Semitism is part of the new technique in world revolution to destroy democracy," marked the opening session today of the National Conference of Jewish Social Welfare which is being held here.

UTICA, N.Y., May 23--Colonel Henry J. Cookinham Jr., State Supreme Court law librarian, veteran Utica lawyer and a leader of troops in both the Spanish-American and World Wars, died here yesterday of heart disease.

Allied steel purchases here total about 500,000 tons, and their direct and indirect purchases are expected to run at that rate each month for the duration of the war, according to Iron Age, which says part of the buying now is in the form of ingots and semi-finished steel and the remainder is finished steel.

Backing President Roosevelt's recommendation for the speeding up of the nation's defense preparations, the Senate yesterday by a vote of 74 to 0 passed the $1,823,000,000 War Department Appropriation Bill and unanimously decided to take up the $1,459,000,000 Navy Appropriation Bill today.

Carmine Scaffo, one of the principal defense witnesses at the murder syndicate trial of Harry (Happy) Maione and Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando, Brooklyn gangsters, returned to the stand in Kings County Court yesterday and delivered a damaging blow to Maione's alibi when he admitted that he had lied before at the order of Maione's brother, whom he feared.

MADRID, May 22--An agreement has been reached between the Spanish Government and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation restoring to the corporation control and management of the Spanish telephone system do the same basis as before the Spanish civil war.

LOUISVILLE, May 22--The committee on State and municipal works of the American Institute of Architects today condemned what it called the continued enoroachment of government bureaus on private architectural practice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22-- Refurbished and retitled after its ill-fated start in February, "The Night of January 16th" has again been placed on Paramount's schedule with Paulette Goddard and Ray Milland as stars.

Freddy Fitzsimmons, fat, but not yet forty, who fits nicely into Lippy Leo Durocher's schemes as a spot pitcher, added another furrow to Frankie Frisch's brow yesterday in the rain at Ebbets Field, where he knuckle-balled the Pirates into submission by a 3-1 count. It was the fifth straight setback for the Pittsburgh club.

An apartment of twelve rooms, comprising an entire floor in the building at 620 Park Avenue, has been leased to Mrs. Egil Boeckman for Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Announcement was made yesterday at a luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund in the Women's Advisory Building at the World's Fair of a $400,000 drive for funds to care for 4,000 needy musicians in I this country. Mrs. Vincent Astor, acting president of the fund, made the announcement in an address to sixty guests.

The Norwegian Consulate General here announced yesterday it had received instructions from the Norwegian Government to register all Norwegian men between the ages of 21 and 45 in the city for possible military service.

BERLIN, May 22--On, the anniversary of the signing of the document that converted the Rome-Berlin Axis info unconditional military alliance for the declared purpose of reorganizing Europe, the press and political circles unanimously proclaim the continued solidarity of the Axis, which "has never trembled for a single day of even a single hour in the past stormy year."
There is a great deal of common sense in Mr. Hoover's remarks on the subject of a "coalition" Government in Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP)--A delegation of Southern members of Congress said today that they had been assured by Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace that he would ask the commodity exchanges to peg the price of lard, which has been sagging.
Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of Brooklyn was elected president of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Associations at the annual meeting held yesterday at headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

The East Tennessee Light and Power Company, a registered holding concern and a subsidiary of the Cities Service Power and Light Company, announced yesterday that holders of more than 97 per cent of the preferred shares of the Tennessee Eastern Electric Company had approved a plan of reorganization...

Ceferino Garcia of Los Angeles, who has never been beaten by a middleweight, will risk his world championship in Madison Square Garden tonight when he encounters Ken Overlin of Washington, D.C., in a scheduled fifteen-round bout. It will mark Garcia's third title defense since he won the 160-pound division laurels last October.

The State of New York has been virtually removed from the union, so far as manufacturers of electrical equipment in other States are concerned, Walter Gordon Merritt declared yesterday in summing up the evidence he had presented in behalf of eleven such manufacturers against Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Eighteen eight-oared shells will row down the Poughkeepsie course in three races the afternoon of Tuesday, June 18, according to the announcement by the board of stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association last night. The draw for lanes for the freshman,

A stiffening in the rates for shortterm municipal paper was emphasized yesterday when the city of Boston, Mass., awarded $5,000,000 temporary-loan notes to the First Boston Corporation at 0.65 per cent plus a premium of $42. The notes, dated May 24, will mature on Nov.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22--President Roosevelt's appointment of Myron C. Taylor as envoy to the Vatican has caused a public clamor far out of proportion to its possible impetus for peace, the Rev. Edwin McNeill Poteat of Cleveland told the Northern Baptist Convention in the Municipal Convention Hall here today.
COPENHAGEN, German-Occupied Denmark (via Berlin), May 22 --With all possible efforts Denmark is striving to counteract the economic difficulties that are the consequence of the German occupation.

Employes of the Parmelee and Terminal Taxicab Systems designated the Transport Workers Union, a C.I.O. affiliate, as their exclusive collective bargaining representative in elections tabulated yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.
Sales and leases of dwellings featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
City College found itself in a winning streak yesterday as it defeated Brooklyn College at Lewisohn Stadium for its third baseball victory within a week. The score was 12 to 5.
PARIS, May 22--As the battle continues to rage in Northern France and in Belgium, foretokens of its progress may be sought today in what the Germans have not done rather than in what they have done.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Harry L. Hopkins, Secretary of Commerce, has been a guest at the White House for ten days or more and there were indications today that he was playing an important role in advising the Administration on the part industrialists should be allowed to take in the drive for defense preparations.

We wonder sometimes whether people get full benefit from our advanced machinery for long-distance communication. In the A.T. T. exhibit yesterday the operator established a 3,400-mile circuit between Misa Foreign Trade (Miss Lois Hering) and Miss San Francisco World's Fair (Miss Lila Deane), who was in the office of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce.

The question whether Kenneth F. Simpson should be ousted from his membership in the national committee of the Republican party before the Philadelphia convention was put yesterday before the State's delegation to the convention.

CHICAGO, May 22--While trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade proceeded rather slowly to day, the better character of the war news from Europe and firmness in securities brought in sufficient buying to more than offset rather concentrated selling of September wheat by a house with Eastern and Northwestern connections.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday met less liquidation and a recovery of cent a pound left the list with gains of 11 to 16 points. After the execution of a few scattered selling orders early, prices advanced about $1 a bale.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The United Light and Power Company won today a new postponemeat of a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing an integration proceedings on the contention that certain issues needed clarifying.

The eight-family apartment house at 43 Lewis Avenue. Brooklyn, has been sold by the Williamsburg Savings Bank to a client of Max Bayer, who plans extensive alterations. The building is four stories and occupies a plot 25 by 100 feet. Charles Buermann Co., Inc., was the broker.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Worker and national vice president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared yesterday that he regarded John L. Lewis's refusal to continue peace negotiations between the C.I.O. and the American Federation of Labor as a "mistake."

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22--Regardless of the developments in the European war, the problem of business recovery in the United States will continue to be one which must be settled from within, according to speakers on a panel discussion at the forty sixth annual convention of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association in the Hotel Traymore tonight.

Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, addressed yesterday a letter to holders of preferred and common stock announcing that a special meeting will be held here on June 20 to act on a proposed increase to $50,000,000 in the aggregate amount

BOSTON, May 22--The Rev. Dr. Frederick William Hamilton of Cambridge, fourth president of Tufts College, serving from April, 1905, to the end of 1913, and a high ranking official in State Masonic circles, died today in a Boston hospital at the age of 80.

Tiny pairs of hands busily wielded miniature rakes, hoes and other farm implements yesterday atop the Children's Aid Society playground building at 419 West Thirtyeighth Street as a dozen children who need extra air and sunshine participated in Spring planting activities in the roof garden.

Recently elected officers of the Student Self-Government Association of Hunter College were inducted at a formal chapel yesterday afternoon in the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, by Ernestine Friedl, retiring president of the association.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22--Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, told shippers and shipping men here today that the American merchant marine was stronger than it had been since the famous clipper ship days and that the government planned to extend its program of construction indefinitely.

A completely equipped ambulance unit, including the driver's maintenance and uniform, will be presented to the American Volunteer Ambulance Corps by the members of the New York Stock Exchange through the New York Stock Exchange Golf Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, its special railroad commission and the Old Colony Railroad all petitioned the interstate Commerce Commission today to reopen the New York, New Haven Hartford
MEXICO CITY, May 22 (UP)-- Concern over the influx of Germans into Mexico has spurted a government investigation of possible fifth column activities, it was reported reliably today.

Too much "confusion of thought, and feeling" and a lack of unity exists in this country about the issues raised by the situation in Europe, William Allan Neilson, former president of Smith College, told the fifteenth annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education at the Hotel Astor last night. This confusion is likely to result, he said, in "paralysis as to action."

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--Michigan's sophomore track talent will be squarely on the spot this weekend in the annual Big Ten outdoor meet at Evanston. It is up to the new Wolverines to take up the slack left by the absence of Big Bill Watson and ailing Ralph Schwarzkopf if Michigan is to annex its fourth straight championship.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would submit to the Federal Communications Commission in "a day or two" his charge that the Columbia Broadcasting System and the Citizens Budget Commission were conspiring to end municipal operation of radio station WNYC.

The Military Training Camps Association, which includes leading New York business and professional men who organized the Plattsburg movement for training officers in the World War, adopted a resolution at a meeting here last night urging the immediate adoption of universal compulsory military training by the Federal Government, with universal service for both men and women in time of war.

LONDON, May 22--Under the combined effect of a healthy technical condition and the close control over new issues the stock markets recovered partly today from the depression caused by war news. At the start of the session prices were marked down to the nominal level, while in some cases business

BERLIN, May 23--Motor trucks able to follow immediately on the heels of the advancing troops are the chief means of transportation for supplies from the Reich to the foremost vanguard of the German armies. Emanuel Hertz, one of Americas outstanding authorities on the life of Abraham Lincoln and author of two books about Lincoln, died yesterday at his home, 17 West Seventy-first Street. Mr. Hertz was stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage a week ago. He was 69 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP)-- Doubles by Bill Nicholson and Al Todd and a single by Bob Mattick gave the Cubs two runs and a 4-to-3 victory over the fighting Phillies in a thirteen-inning game at Shibe Park tonight.

CHICAGO, May 23--Fluctuations in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today were largely the result of professional efforts to follow the war news from Western Europe. A moderate advance early was followed by a break of about 2 cents a bushel from the top when ...

A warning that failure to provide adequate police protection against vandalism in the parks and playgrounds will result in their "returning to their former shabbiness," was sounded yesterday by Allyn R. Jennings, general superintendent of the Department of Parks, during the first tour of the Park Association of New York to Brooklyn since 1937.

As two leaders of Brooklyn's "murder syndicate" were convicted yesterday in Kings County Court of murder in the first degree, Dis trict Attorney William O'Dwyer's drive against crime was extended by a new batch of murder indictments, among them one against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, convicted racketeer serving a fourteen-year sentence in Federal prison.

Rene Dreyfus and Rene Le Begue, French racing drivers, who got leave from the French military authorities to race at Indianapolis on Memorial Day, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. They left immediately for Indianapolis.

Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the New York City school system since 1924, announced yesterday that he intends to retire from active service at the end of this year. He will take a month's vacation in July and then go on leave of absence until Jan. 1, 1941, when his retirement becomes effective.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce presented to President Roosevelt today a resolution pledging its "full" aid in carrying out the defense program on the industrial and commercial fronts.

Winner at Aiken and Camden, but defeated in a previous start at Belmont Park, Massa from the John Hay Whitney barn yesterday captured the Spring Maiden Steeplechase, second of the sporting races which are being run as a three-ply event. Going powerfully at the end of the two miles, the gelded son of Black Toney had three lengths to spare when he was timed in 3:57 2-5 over a sloppy track.

LONDON, May 23-The blackest news of the war thus far came today when Prime Minister Churchill rose in the House of Commons to announce tersely that German armored forces had reached the English Channel and were now engaged.

A town house in the upper Fifth Avenue area that was erected at the turn of the century will be converted into modern apartments as the result of the sale yesterday of 8 East Eighty-third Street, adjoining the avenue and near the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Long after the Giants and Dodgers had called off yesterday's games because of rain, wet grounds, threatening weather and what-not, Secretary Eddie Brannick of the New York club continued to peer into the skies and consult a half dozen assorted barometers. Eddie was far more concerned with atmospheric conditions for today.

CAMP BEAUREGARD, La., May 23--The Third Army staged a thrilling battle today, employing a large air force in coordination with ground forces to test the methods of the German Army in its thrust against the Allies.

The Continental Aviation and Engineering Corporation plans to file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 260,000 shares of common stock, it was announced yesterday by C.J. Reese, president. It will be the first public financing for the corporation, which was incorporated recently as a subsidiary of the Continental Motors Corporation.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23-- Piloted splendidly by Carl Schilling of Bristol, Pa., Lady Luck, 7-yearold black mare, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Hale Steinman of Lancaster, today gained valuable points in the first event of the three-day jumping competition which featured the opening of the Wilmington horse show.

The rush of men seeking work at the New York Navy Yard continued unabated yesterday, reaching new heights since the flood of applications started Monday after the President announced an inten sified program for national defense.

BOSTON, May 23 (AP)--Former President Herbert Hoover asserted in s speech here tonight that "here in America was the last chance of making the system of liberty vital to men." He added that this country had the double duty of repairing democracy's failures and of constantly rebuilding it.

WASHINGTON, May 23-Registration of the 3,500,000 aliens in the United States as a defense measure to combat the activities of a "fifth column" was proposed by Attorney General Jackson today in connection with the transfer of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to the Department of Justice.

A landmark in the Bronx that cradled the motion-picture industry in its infancy has been sold by the heirs of Thomas A. Edison, a pioneer in the field. The property is at 2826 Decatur Avenue, corner of Oliver Street, and is the original Edison studio and one of the first of its kind in this country.

Ralph Miller Johnson of Belfast, Me., a former railroad executive and stock broker who was long a resident here, died suddenly of a heart attack at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton, Boston, on Wednesday, according to word received here yesterday. His age was 67.

J. Russet Sprague, campaign manager for Thomas E. Dewey, declared yesterday that there had been no indication of diminution of either popular or delegate support for the District Attorney as candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination since Germany's inva-...

The three alleged "Nazi agents" who were forced by the police of Del Rio, Texas, to leave town, were identified here yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union as members of a religious sect known as Jehovah's Witnesses.

WASHINGTON, May 26--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, and twenty stars of the stage, radio and screen today appealed over the radio to Americans to contribute to the $10,000,000 fund sought by the Red Cross for the relief of war refugees in Europe.
BOSTON, May 26--Any doubt concerning the ability of the Yankees as mudders was dispelled this wintry afternoon.
Miss Margaret MacKenzie Treadway and William Milligan Sloan, whose engagement was announced in November, will be married on June 25 in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

Net railway operating income of $197,585 is reported by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company for the month of April, a decrease of $316,169 compared with a year ago. Gross revenues were $6,443,365, a decrease of $300,231, or 4.5 per cent.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 26-- The whole of Egypt will be blacked out at night in the future instead of only along the sea front. Both at Alexandria and at Cairo this move has naturally given rise to many rumors.

WASHINGTON, May 26--A rapidly expanding Agricultural Adjustment Administration program is helping American farmers to shift from exploitative to soil-conserving farming and tiding them over adjustments accompanying the European war, the report of the AAA for 1939, issued today, asserted.

Returning from Puerto Rico, Admiral Leahy declares that our island base there, once completed, will make it impossible for any European Power to land an expeditionary force on the southern coast of the United States, Central America or the northern shores of South America.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)--Cooperation between the United States and Ecuador on measures to safeguard the Panama Canal was indicated today by disclosure that military and naval officers of the two countries had just ended a series of conferences.
PICTOU, N.S., May 26 (Canadian Press)--Edward Mortimer Macdonald, former Liberal Minister of National Defense, died here yesterday in his home, at the age of 74.

PARIS, May 26--Despite severe losses, the Germans have not ceased their pressure in Flanders. Apart from the loss of Boulogne the Allies have withstood it everywhere, according to the latest reports received tonight. On broad lines that is the day's story. Tildsley, retired associate superintendent of the New York City schools, urged the teaching profession to concern itself more with the children entrusted in its care rather than the building of a new social order.

MEXICO CITY, May 26--Police have started a search for an American named George Mink in connection with the attempted assassination Friday of Leon Trotsky, exiled Communist leader, it was reported tonight.

CINCINNATI, May 26 (AP)--Paul Derringer, who has had trouble getting his sights lined this season, allowed the Cardinals one hit today and gave the Reds a 4-to-0 victory. The big hurler, who won twentyfive games for Cincinnati last year, struck out seven men.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, May 27--The heaviest casualties since the big Japanese raids on Chungking in May of last year were caused when an estimated ninetythree Japanese planes bombed the suburbs of this capital yesterday noon. WASHINGTON, May 26 (UP)--Military and civilian aviation leaders tonight pledged their best efforts to expedite President Roosevelt's long-range program of 50,000 Army and Navy planes and his plans for training 50,000 civilian pilots.

Following the celebration of National Bottled Carbonated Beverage Week, just ended, makers of soft drinks will put their Summer selling programs in high gear this week. Jimmy McGuire's goal midway in the second period enabled an American League all-star combination to come from behind and tie Mexico's national soccer champions, the Club Atlante, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

Changes in service on the Fulton Street, Lexington Avenue and Culver lines in Brooklyn to conform with the city's operating plans after it takes over the B.M.T. system were announced yesterday by the company.

Solution of the unemployment problem will be sought at an Interfaith Conference on Unemployment in Washington from June 4 to 6, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Research and Education of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Saul Elman, father of Mischa Elman, the violinist, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had been ill for two weeks. His age was 76.

LONDON, May 26--In the terrific battle now going on to defend the Channel ports so dangerously near England, British troops are in action side by side with their allies and, "fighting magnificently," have repulsed all attacks, it is officially reported here tonight.
PARIS, May 26--The statement of the Bank of France, dated May 16, shows an increase of 2,160,000,000 francs in circulation, which was predicted the preceding week as inevitable.

TOKYO, May 27--United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew today gave to an influential Japanese audience one of the most telling expositions they had heard of, American ideals in international policy.

William Lawson Little Jr., former grand-slam amateur golf champion of the United States and Great Britain, came into his own as a professional yesterday as 139 survivors of a field of more than 1,100 earned starting places in the 1940 national open championship.

Albany, N.Y., will be in the market on June 4 with $2,405,006 of bonds for various purposes. Bidders are to name the rate of interest. LONDON, May 27--General Maxime Weygand, it was reported today, assumed the French High Command after a dramatic airplane dash from Syria through a storm in which his plane was cracked up during a forced landing.

WASHINGTON, May 27--The machinery which has trained 10,000 civilian pilots throughout the country in the past year can be geared up to turn out 50,000 in the coming year, according to a statement today by Robert H. Hinckley, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Authority and chief sponsor of the plan.
For some time we have heard these stories concerning the Connecticut River shad and their tendency to take a certain fly during the course of their run up the river and its many feeders.

WASHINGTON, May 27--Jay Pierrepont Moffat, chief of the European Division of the State Department and veteran career diplomat, was appointed by President Roosevelt today Minister to Canada to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of James H.R. Cromwell.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 27--At tempts "to conquer other peoples under the urge of warlike fanaticism," such as actuates the Nazis, "are always fatal to those who launch them," Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, French Ambassador, said today, in his Phi Beta Kappa address at the commencement of Hobart and William Smith College.
Apartment leasing on Park and Fifth Avenues continues at a rapid pace, reports received yesterday from brokers operating in that section of the city indicate.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 27-- James D. Craig, who retired last January as vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company after forty-three years of serv ice, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 62 years old and had lived here since his childhood.

DEVON, Pa., May 27--Miss Deborah C. Rood of Wilmington, Del., piloting her gray gelding Silver Clay, beat keen competition to win in a large field of green hunters today at the opening of the six-day Devon Horse Show, America's most famous outdoor tanbark classic.

Three defendants, one of whom testified that his brother was a high officer in the German Army, took the witness chair yesterday in the United States District Court in Brooklyn, where they are on trial with eleven other men for conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government and to steal government munitions.

Dr. Nan Gilbert Seymour, medical director since its founding of the William Booth Memorial Hospital, maintained by the Salvation Army at 314 East Fifteenth Street, and a pioneer in hospital social service worn, died yesterday at the hospital after an illness of several months.

WASHINGTON, May 27--In an interpretation of the Chandler Act, 1938 revision of the Bankruptcy Act, the Supreme Court sustained today the power of the Securities and Exchange Commission to participate in a financial adjustment. The decision agreed with the SEC that Chapter X, rather than Chapter XI, was appropriate in the bankruptcy case at issue.
BERLIN, May 27--Prince Wilhelm of Prussia, 34 years old, eldest son of the former Crown Prince, died yesterday in a field hospital as a result of wounds received on the Western Front.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27-- Frank Craven, who last was seen on the screen as the narrator in Sol Lesser's "Our Town," was signed today by Warners for a similar role in "City for Conquest" ...

WASHINGTON, May 27--The Timm Aircraft Corporation of Van Nuys, Calif., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 215,835 shares of $1-par common stock. The company makes training planes and parts for other airplane manufacturers.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, told 20,000 members of his organization at Madison Square Garden yesterday that the failure of the American Federation of Labor to oust racketeers from positions of leadership in its affiliated unions made it impossible for the I.L.G.W.U. to return to the federation.

The Swiss Government has chartered fifteen Greek freighters to serve as supply ships for its industries and military forces, it was disclosed yesterday at the Swiss Consulate General, 444 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 27--The export trade of the United States in April declined almost 8 per cent from the March level. Imports were down only slightly. The decrease in imports was less than $5,000,000 or 2 per cent from March, to $212,000,000 in April, and represented about the usual seasonal change. It was, however, about $32,000,000 lower in comparison with the monthly average of the December-January imports.

LONDON, May 27--A week-end along the English Channel gave this correspondent some idea of the confident tenacity with which the ordinary inhabitants of those areas are witnessing the battle which concerns them so deeply. They can see it and hear more of it.

ROME, May 27--The Holy See has yielded to the demands of the Italian Government and starting today the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano has reappeared on newsstands in Italy as a shadow of its former self.

As the World's Fair observed the seventeenth day of the 1940 season yesterday, still hounded by rain and unfavorable weather, exposition officials, frankly disappointed by the total paid attendance of 1,304,075 through Sunday, opened a drive to prove to the public they are offering "the biggest 50 cents' worth of entertainment in the world." They hope the tide will turn with the four-day holiday week-end starting next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 27--A move to enact a defense tax bill at this session of Congress took sudden and definite form today as Administration authorities and Congressional revenue leaders reached a tentative conclusion to act at once upon the country's evident willingness to bear directly the added burdens necessary to preparedness.

WASHINGTON, May 27--A tenmonth trend was reversed in February when foreign investors bought more United States securities than they sold, according to the May issue of The Treasury Bulletin, made public today.
TRENTON, N.J., May 27--It seemed almost certain tonight that the Newark airport would be closed on Friday.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., May 27--The uncertainty of golf was brought home to Ben Hogan today when he failed to gain one of the seventeen places allotted to the metropolitan district for the national open championship, which is to be played at the Canterbury Club in Cleveland June 6-8.

BERLIN, May 27--President Roosevelt's week-end fireside talk on the state of the defenses of the United States evoked only cursory comment in German quarters which were inclined to appraise his justification of huge armanent expenditures as designed purely for home consumption.

The directors of the United Aircraft Corporation approved yesterday plans for a further $8,000,000 expansion of its Pratt Whitney Aircraft Division, already tripled in capacity in little more than twelve months. Completion of the additional facilities is expected within three months.
The free-market pound fluctuated here yesterday between $3.20 and $3.18 7/8, and closed at $3.19 off cent on the day. The French franc eased 1 point on the day to end at 1.80 cents.

WASHINGTON, May 27--The Federal Communications Commission announced tonight that full commercial operation of television would be permitted when, and only when, the engineering opinion of the industry was prepared to approve any one of the present competing systems.

WASHINGTON, May 27--The La Follette Civil Liberties Bill was passed by the Senate late today, 47 to 20, but only after being amended to a fragment of its original form and turned into something of a "defense" measure by the inclusion of provisions to limit the employment of aliens in industry.
Commercial organizations whose growth has forced them to seek new and larger quarters figured largely in the rental activity reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27--George Lamaze, nationally known restaurateur, who had been executive vice president of the Warwick Hotel here since 1935, died of heart disease in his apartment at the hotel late this afternoon. His health had been failing for some time. He was 53 years old.

ALEXANDRIA, La., May 27 (AP)-- L.P. Abernathy, former chairman of the Louisiana Highway Commission, and George Younger, an Alexandria truck driver, co-defendants with former Governor Richard W. Leche on mail-fraud charges, pleaded guilty today.

KISHINEV, Bessarabia, Rumania, May 27--The whole of Northern Bessarabia, which formerly belonged to Russia, has been turned into a huge workshop by the Rumanians. Great numbers of laborers are toiling at top speed to finish fortification lines at the earliest possible moment.

Plans to renovate a West Side apartment house were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the six-story elevator building at 343-5 West Eighty-fifth Street by the 343-5 West Eightyfifth Street Corporation from the Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 27--Formation of a War Industries Board responsible directly to the President to supervise industrial mobilization for defense and not a coordinating agency in which industrial experts would be responsible to departmental officials was recommended in the still secret report of the advisory board headed by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., which was disbanded after war started last Fall.

The new $6.66 tires introduced by the leading manufacturers will eliminate the necessity for the widely criticized "50 per cent off" sales of last year on national brands, it was pointed out here yesterday. ABOUT eighty years ago a man was digging in a gravel pit near Abbeville, in Northern France--the same Abbeville that the Germans took the other day. His name was Boucher de Perthes. He held a post in the French customs service and worked as an amateur archaeologist on the side.

BOSTON, May 27--Maybe they were depressed by playing before only 1,415 persons, or it may have been that the Bees finally tired of being kicked around all season by the Giants. Whatever the cause, Casey Stengel's lads up and beat the Terrymen today for the first time this year. They did a mighty impressive job, winning by 7 to 1.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., May 27-- On links made heavy by recent rain, Miss Laddie Irwin of Upper Montclair led a field of 100 in the first round of the fifteenth annual New Jersey Women's Golf Association closed championship today. She posted 40, 45--85 over the lower course of the Baltusrol Club.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co, offered yesterday to the public most of the unsubscribed portion of the 110,909 shares of $1 par value common stock of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., at $30.75 a share. A combination of buying by foreign and domestic trade interests was the source of further improvement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices at the close were 11 to 16 points better than Saturday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The American Red Cross asked its 3,700 chapters today to raise a fund of $20,000,000 or more for war relief. This is double the amount originally asked, which Norman H. Davis, chairman stated in a telegram to the chapters should now be regarded as only a minimum immediate objective.

Another non-profit medical insurance corporation received a permit yesterday from the State Insurance Department to solicit subscribers in New York City, Westchester and Nassau Counties The company, known as the Medical Guild Foundation, cannot assume full function until it gets a license from the State.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The $3,300,000,000 emergency rearmament program went ahead at full speed to day as President Roosevelt revived the Council of National Defense and Congressional and Administration leaders agreed to rush through new defense taxes at this session to provide about $700,000,000 a year to finance the huge outlay.

WASHINGTON, May 28--The President followed very sensible, obvious and disinterested advice when he decided, as he announced today, to conduct the defense preparedness program within the framework of the statute of Aug. 29, 1916, which was used by President Wilson and was never repealed. The setup proved highly effective in 1917-19.

Discontinuance of the five-cent pedestrian tolls on the George Washington Bridge and the three Staten Island spans to New Jersey was announced yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

DEVON, Pa., May 28--The first night program of the Devon Horse Show proved a big success from the standpoint of the spectators, a crowd of 8,200 witnessing tonight's events. There were thrills galore due to the spills which were absent during the two previous daylight shows.

The graduating class of Lincoln School, 425 West 123d Street, refusing to accept a traditional formal commencement with an outside speaker, yesterday staged its own idea of what a commencement program should be.

WASHINGTON, May 29--On the eve of his first meeting with the reconstituted Council of National Defense, President Roosevelt was putting finishing touches today on a new request for $750,000,000 as a supplemental appropriation for further expansion and mechanization of the military establishment to take account of European war developments since he sent his preparedness message to Congress two weeks ago.

NOW for one of the big days of the sports year--if the Weather Man will be a gentle man for a change! Horse and auto racing, golf, tennis, baseball and allied exercises are on the program and it's about time for a good spell of sunshine.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29--Federal Circuit Court Judge William Clark, a major in the Army during the World War, seeks appointment as a major in the United States Army Field Artillery Reserves.

Employers, labor leaders, consumers, economists and government officials will seek a solution of economic problems, especially those dealing with re-employment, at the Interfaith Conference on Unemployment, which opens in Washington next Tuesday, the Rev. James Myers, industrial secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, announced yesterday at his office, 297 Fourth Avenue.

Peacetime war on a large scale, with bats as the weapons and baseballs as the missiles, will break out on all major league fronts today, with chief public interest in these parts centered upon the three local clubs, the Yankees, Dodgers and Giants.
Arnold Steindler, president of the Home Diathermy Company, has purchased from A. Ruth Sons the ten-room residence at 101 Lincoln Boulevard, Long Beach, Nassau County, for a Summer home.

Several large sales of properties on the upper West Side of Manhattan were reported yesterday. One of the chief deals involved the two five-story garden-type apartment houses at 95-105 and 107-109 Elwood Street, at the corner of Sherman Avenue in the Dyckman section, overlooking Fort Tryon Park.

The action of President Roosevelt in appointing an Advisory National Defense Commission, instead of reorganizing the War and Navy Departments and naming an industrialist to take charge of production of munitions, will disappoint the American people, Herbert Hoover declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May. 29--Mayor La Guardia of New York City advocated today in an address at the National Air Forum legislation to give President Roosevelt discretionary power to establish a virtual dictatorship over airplane production. The proposal would make it possible in case of necessity to declare a "production emergency" with respect to airplanes and certain other equipment needed for quick delivery to the Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Federal Communications Commission completed today its hearing opened on the application of WNYC, New York's municipal radio station, for permission to remain in operation up to 11 P.M. daily on the 810-kilocycle channel shared with it by WCCO, owned and operated by the Columbia Broadcasting System at Minneapolis.

The City Planning Commission concedes that the amendments to the zoning resolution which it has adopted by a 4-to-2 vote "are so complex that even a full reading of the text may not render them altogether clear." This is not the Commission's fault. Ours just happens to be a complex city in a complex civilization.

LONDON, May 29--Further tightening of regulations governing the movements of aliens--even Americans--together with a frank speech by Harold Nicolson, writer and disciple of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who is the new Parliamentary secretary of the Ministry of Information, emphasized tonight how real the expectation, though not fear, of a German invasion has become in the last few days.

TRENTON, May 29--Governor Moore will go to Washington next Wednesday to seek authorization from the National Guard Bureau to form an anti-aircraft unit in the New Jersey National Guard and to find out the attitude of Federal authorities toward a proposal that New Jersey organize a home defense force of war veterans.

WASHINGTON, May 29--An application covering the proposed acquisition by Hudson River Power Corporation of the assets of System Properties, Inc., and the refunding of $14,135,000 of 5 per cent first refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1947, of the International Paper Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MOSCOW, May 29 (AP)--PremierForeign Minister Vyacheslaff Molotoff was reported today to have warned Lithuania that the Soviet Government would take action unless the alleged kidnapping of Soviet soldiers stationed on Lithuanian soil was stopped.
