INDIANAPOLIS, May 29--A bomb will burst at 10 A.M. (Central standard time) tomorrowweather permitting--and thirtythree, or perhaps only thirty-two, stiff-helmeted race drivers will roar off, before some 125,000 spectators, in a grueling four-hour test of men and motors--the twenty-eighth annual 500-mile auto race.
WASHINGTON, May 29--Captain Robert Potter Molten, commanding officer of the aircraft carrier Saratoga, died yesterday at sea aboard his ship. His age was 53.

Advertisements carrying what is described as the first pledge of industry's wholehearted cooperation with the national air expansion program will be placed by the Union Pacific Railroad in three weekly magazines. They are in the form of an open letter by William M. Jeffers, president.

Steady to firm markets characterized trading here yesterday in the pound sterling and the French franc. There was little pressure of offerings from Latin America or the Far East in the pound, and the demand from United States commercial interests was moderately active.

CHICAGO, May 29--The country was advised today to stop worrying about the possibility that the $19,000,000,000 of gold owned by the United States will lose its value. The advice was given by Dr. E.A. Goldenweiser, director of research and statistics of the Federal Reserve Board, in an address made before the Illinois Bankers Association convention.

Memorial Day was born of an old war, among people who still mourned their youthful and untimely dead. Those were boys whose faces had scarcely felt the razor who lay in the fresh graves in the churchyards and the military cemeteries.

The first step in a plan sponsored jointly by the Near East Foundation of New York and the Greek Government to raise the standards of nursing in Greece will be completed with the graduation of Miss Marietta.

ROCHESTER, May 29--Furnishing war materials to aggressor nations was condemned today "as immoral and un-Christian" in a statement adopted by the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. The closing session of the annual meeting also approved plans for raising $125,000 for emergency needs of the church in foreign fields affected by war and nationalism.

The Lehnerts Rock Garden on the Bronx campus of Hunter College, Navy Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard, was dedicated yesterday afternoon by Dr. George N. Shuster, president-elect of Hunter. More than 350 students, staff members and guests were present on the grounds adjacent to the garden.
The State Department yesterday requested operators of American vessels in the Mediterranean service to give preference to citizens of the United States who want to come home from warring Europe.

More than 1,200 persons attended a testimonial dinner to the Rev. John F. White, pastor of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Stapleton, S.I., at the Hotel Commodore last night in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.

A duplex penthouse of twelve rooms and six baths in the cooperative apartment house at 149 East Seventy-third Street has been leased to Thomas Catesby Jones, the attorney, for Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents, by the Madison Realty Company.

Racing at Belmont Park probably will reach its peak for the meeting today with a holiday card headed by the Suburban Handicap at a mile and a quarter, for which a dozen of the best horses in training are named. If all start, the race will have a gross value of $27,700.

BERLIN, May 29--Prince Wilhelm of Prussia, 34 years old and the eldest son of the former Crown Prince, was buried in Potsdam this afternoon with the military honors customary for a first lieutenant who dies as the result of wounds received in battle.

Sir Walter Roper Lawrence, who had a distinguished career in the Civil Service in India, died on Saturday at the home of his son, Captain Neville Lawrence, in Woking, Surrey, England, according to word received here by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, President of Columbia University. Captain Lawrence is the husband of Dr. Butler's daughter, the former Miss Sarah Schuyler Butler.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29 (AP)-- Six-foot six-inch Wilburn Butland made his major-league pitching debut with the first-place Boston Red Sox today by whipping Philadelphia, 8--3.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The way was opened today for expediting deliveries of American airplanes to the Allied fighting lines when Secretary Hull modified regulations of the Neutrality Act to permit the delivery of such aircraft by American pilots to ports in the three eastern Canadian Provinces.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Senate Naval Committee said today that "a reputable scientist" had reported discovery of an explosive about 100 times more powerful than TNT, most destructive of World War explosives.

CHICAGO, May 29--Pre-holiday evening-up operations, combined with pronounced strength in Winnipeg and an upturn in securities, resulted in prices of wheat on the Board of Trade advancing around 1 cent a bushel at one time today.

Reacting from an oversold condition, the stock market erased yesterday the losses of Tuesday and added moderately to the value of securities, although the volume of trading was slowed down by the usual pre-holiday inertia.
CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP)--Bob Feller was below his best form today, but, aided by the Indians' fourteen-hit attack, had enough to trim Detroit, 7 to 4, for his seventh triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 29--Two more Red Cross workers and additional quantities of emergency relief supplies for France will be on board the liner Washington when she sails tomorrow. A cable reporting the arrival in Paris by air via Lisbon of a previous delegation of three representatives and an important consignment of medical supplies was received at national headquarters.

CHICAGO, May 10 (AP)--The American Olympic Committee's plans for giving Uncle Sam's track and field stars a consolation meet in lieu of the international games abandoned by Finland were canceled today.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Senate Democrats engaged in a spirited quarrel today over the status of the Logan-Walter bill to give the right of appeal to Federal courts from Administrative orders by Federal agencies. It has already been approved by the House.

The Japanese apparently desire to convince all whom it may concern that they, too, can do things with airplanes. Since Sunday they have been raiding Chungking, the Chinese capital on the upper Yangtze, every day.

WASHINGTON, May 30--Income payments to individuals in the United States in the first four months of this year amounted to $23,500,000,000, an increase of 5 per cent over payments in the corresponding months of 1939, the Department of Commerce announced today.

President Roosevelt drafted a message to be sent to Congress today requesting $1,000,000,000 more for the national defense as a result of developments in Europe in the last two weeks. WASHINGTON, May 30--United States export trade in food products in April declined 7 per cent from April, 1939, chiefly due to a drop in wheat exports, but the trade was marked by an increase in shipments of canned food products to the United Kingdom despite the imposition of import restrictions, the Commerce Department announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 30-- According to reports from the northern Swedish-Norwegian frontier, the Germans from Narvik have fortified themselves in seven mountain tunnels on a short stretch of the iron ore railroad to the Swedish frontier and are contesting every inch of ground.

JERSEY CITY, May 30 (AP)--Jersey City and Newark divided a doubleheader today before 17,223 fans, the Little Giants winning the opener, 4 to 1, and the Bears taking the nightcap, 3 to 0.

The desperate drive of the Yankees to gain on the American League leaders was headed for success yesterday when, amid the thunderous roars of a crowd of 82,437, the Bronx Bombers repulsed the front-running Red Sox, 4 to 0, in the opening clash of the doubleheader at the Stadium.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP)--Walter Ridenour's Morcarine, outsider in the field of eight starters at 27-1, won the third running of the $5,000 added Memorial Handicap of six furlongs at Suffolk Downs today before a near-capacity throng of 46,500.
DETROIT, May 30 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers strengthened their hold on third place in the American League by sweeping a double-header today from the St. Louis Browns.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP)-- After winning the first game, 7 to 6, with a two-run rally in the ninth inning, the Athletics lost the second half of a double-header to the Senators in seven innings today, 14 to 2. The nightcap was called because of darkness.

CHICAGO, May 30--Cincinnati's Reds came through under pressure today like the champions they are, regaining first place in the National League by taking two games from the Chicago Cubs as Brooklyn lost twice to the New York Giants.

Bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the six business days ended on Wednesday were $5,717,548,000, or 32.5 per cent more than in the same week of 1939, which included Memorial Day and therefore had only five business days, in which clearings were $4,314,948,000.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 30--Golf came into prominence today at Meadow Brook, where polo usually reigns. The first part of the qualifying round in the club's annual invitation team tournament was staged.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30 --Frank Shields and Clifford Sutter, ranked high among the elect of amateur tennis a few years ago, were in surprisingly good form today as they qualified for the quarter-finals of the invitation tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Babe Bower, national 150-mile champion, of Philadelphia won the 30-lap final which featured the weekly program of midget automobile races before 7,000 persons at the Thompson Stadium in Stapleton, S.I., last night. The twenty-fifth annual commencement of the Lenox School will take place at 11 A.M. tomorrow at its new building, 170 East Seventieth Street. Nine young women will be graduated.

WASHINGTON, June 3--Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today that engineers were selecting a standardized motor suitable for military aircraft. This, he added, must be done before the automobile plants could go to work. The British Merlin, twelve-cylinder RollsRoyce engine, rated among the best owned by the Allies, was one of those under consideration, he added.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 3 (AP)-- Favorites breezed through the opening round or the New England tennis championships at the Hartford Golf Club in impressive style today.

A $320,000 mortgage for ten years at 4 per cent on the seven-story apartment house with stores nearing completion at the southwest corner of Sheridan Avenue and 163d Street, the Bronx, has been arranged for Abe Spires by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers.

LONDON, June 3 (AP)--Norwegian refugees reported that British warships had forced their way into Rana Fjord and attacked German forces in Mo, Northern Norway, says an Exchange Telegraph Agency dispatch today quoting a Swedish newspaper.
WASHINGTON, June 3--A conference of House Republicans unanimously demanded today that Congress stay in session, "as long as the interest of the country requires."

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 3-- Commencement exercises of the Vail-Deane School will be held here tomorrow at Westminster Presbyterian Church. Special awards will be presented, among them the Class of 1937 emblem, awarded annually in memory of Marjorie Moffat Charlock.

Of these, 222 were ships of the Royal Navy and 665 were small merchant or private vessels impressed into the operation.

Columbus, Ohio, June 3 (AP)--Jack (Buddy) Walker of Columbus scored his twentieth victory tonight with little oppostion from Eddie Mader, New York boxer. Mader's handlers threw in the towel at 1:55 of the fourth round. Walker weighed 194 and Mader 189.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 80.3 per cent of capacity, compared with 76.9 per cent the week before, a gain of 3.4 points, or 4.4 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 3--By a voice vote with no dissent the Senate passed in three minutes late today the House bill authorizing a further outlay of $654,902,270 for the Navy to increase its fighting ships by 11 per cent.

PARIS, June 3--To German assertions that from the military point of view this is the beginning of the end for the Allies, the French retort today that it is merely the end of the beginning.
In a formal announcement here yesterday the Schenley Distillers Corporation confirmed reports that it will market certain of its domestic brands direct to retailers in the local market.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3--Officials of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, airplane manufacturers, at a conference here today asked the Essex County Board of Freeholders to close a road so the corporation's airport at Caldwell could be enlarged.

The New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad has opened a new building to house its freight terminal in Edgewater, N.J. Traffic through that point, the most important terminal of the line, yields gross revenues of $6,000,000 annually.

NEWARK, June 3 (AP)--With Outfielder Buddy Bates collecting a homer, two doubles and two singles in six trips, the Toronto Leafs today conquered the Newark Bears, 11 to 9, and moved closer to the first division.

Pete Lello, who knocked out Lew Jenkins before the latter won the lightweight championship, will trade punches with Vic Troise of the Bronx in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena tonight. Leonard W. Mayo, associate executive director of the Welfare Council, has been elected president of the Child Welfare League of America, it was announced yesterday at national headquarters, 130 East Twenty-second Street. He succeeds Paul T. Beisser, president for the last two years.

WASHINGTON, June 3--At her press conference today Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt advocated a "compulsory training service" program to prepare all young people for any national emergency, including war. She cautioned that this idea was not to be confused with compulsory military training, to which she was opposed.

TOURS, France, June 3 (UP)-- Fernand Gravey, Parisian actor who starred in the Hollywood comedy "The King and the Chorus Girl" a few years ago with Joan Blondell, joined the French ambulance unit assigned to the military hospital here today. CAIRO, Egypt, June 3--With the shadow of war steadily drifting nearer, tension increased today as Egypt faced the future, but at the same time resolution was evident. Miss Helen Marot, former member of the editorial board of The Dial and writer on economics and sociology, died yesterday at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals after a short illness. She was 75 years old and lived at 165 West Twelfth Street.
